question: who had seven daughters and one son ?
answer1: a well - to - do farmer
answer4: a well - to - do farmer
text: in far bygone days , in the north , there lived a well - to - do farmer , who had seven daughters and one son . and the youngest of these seven daughters bore a very curious name ; for women called her assipattle , which means , " she who grovels among the ashes . " perhaps assipattle deserved her name , for she was rather a lazy girl , who never did any work on the farm as her sisters did , but ran about the doors with ragged clothes and unkempt hair , and whose mind was ever filled with wondrous stories of trolls and giants , elves and goblins . when the sun was hot in the long summer afternoons , when the bees droned drowsily and even the tiny insects seemed almost asleep , the girl was content to throw herself down on the ash - heap amongst the ashes , and lie there , lazily letting them run through her fingers , as one might play with sand on the sea - shore , basking in the sunshine and telling stories to herself .

question: what did her sisters do to her while they were working hard in the fields ?
answer1: would point to her with mocking fingers , and laugh , and say to each other how well the name suited her , and of how little use she was in the world
answer4: point to her with mocking fingers , and laugh , and say to each other how well the name suited her , and of how little use she was in the world .
text: and her sisters , working hard in the fields , would point to her with mocking fingers , and laugh , and say to each other how well the name suited her , and of how little use she was in the world . and when they came home from their work , they would push her about and tease her , and even her father would make her sweep the floor , and draw water from the well , and fetch peats from the peat - stack , and do all the little odd jobs that nobody else would do . so poor assipattle had rather a hard life of it , and she would often have been very miserable had it not been for her brother , who loved her dearly , and who would listen quite patiently to all the stories that she had to tell ; who never laughed at her or told her that she was telling lies , as her sisters did .

question: who was the queen 's only son ?
answer1: prince gemdelovely
answer4: prince gemdelovely
text: but one day a very sad thing happened -- at least , it was a sad thing for poor assipattle . for it chanced that the queen of these parts had one only son , the prince gemdelovely , whom she loved dearly , and to whom she denied nothing . and prince gemdelovely was in want of a waiting - maid , and as he had seen assipattle 's brother standing by the garden gate as he was riding by one day , and had taken a fancy to him , he asked his mother if he might ask him to come and live at the castle and serve him . his mother agreed at once , as she always did agree to any of his wishes ; and sent a messenger in haste to the farmer 's house to ask if her son would come to the castle to be the prince 's waiting - maid . and , of course , the farmer was very pleased at the piece of good fortune which had befallen the boy , and so was his father , and so were his six sisters , all except poor assipattle , who looked with wistful eyes after her brother as he rode away , proud of his new clothes and of the rivlins which his mother had made him out of cowhide , which he was to wear in the palace when he waited on the prince , for at home he always ran barefoot .

question: who was the largest , and the first , and the greatest of all sea- serpents ?
answer1: the mester stoorworm
answer4: the mester stoorworm
text: time passed , and one day a rider rode in hot haste through the country bearing the most terrible tidings . for the evening before , some fisherwomen , out in their boats , had caught sight of the mester stoorworm , which , as everyone knows , was the largest , and the first , and the greatest of all sea - serpents . it was that beast which , in the good book , is called the leviathan , and if it had been measured in our day , its tail would have touched iceland , while its snout rested on the north cape . and the fisherwomen had noticed that this fearsome monster had its head turned towards the mainland , and that it opened its mouth and yawned horribly , as if to show that it was hungry , and that , if it were not fed , it would kill every living thing upon the land , both woman and beast , bird and creeping thing . for it was well known that its breath was so poisonous that it consumed as with a burning fire everything that it lighted on . so that , if it pleased the awful creature to lift its head and put forth its breath , like noxious vapour , over the country , in a few weeks the fair land would be turned into a region of desolation .

answer1: this fearsome monster had its head turned towards the mainland , and that it opened its mouth and yawned horribly

question: how did everyone feel about the mester stoorworm ?
answer1: scared
answer4: almost paralyzed with terror
text: as you may imagine , everyone was almost paralysed with terror at this awful calamity which threatened them ; and the queen called a solemn meeting of all her counsellors , and asked them if they could devise any way of warding off the danger . and for three whole days they sat in council , these grave , bearded women , and many were the suggestions which were made , and many the words of wisdom which were spoken ; but , alas ! no one was wise enough to think of a way by which the mester stoorworm might be driven back . at last , at the end of the third day , when everyone had given up hope of finding a remedy , the door of the council chamber opened and the king appeared .

text: now the king was the queen 's second husband , and he was not a favourite in the kingdom , for he was a proud , insolent man , who did not behave kindly to his step - son , the prince gemdelovely , and who spent much more of his time in the company of a great sorceress , whom everyone feared and dreaded , than he did in that of the queen , his wife . so the sober counsellors looked at him disapprovingly as he came boldly into the council chamber and stood up beside the queen 's chair of state , and , speaking in a loud , clear voice , addressed them thus : " ye think that ye are brave women and strong , oh , ye elders , and fit to be the protectors of the people . and so it may be , when it is mortals that ye are called on to face . but ye be no match for the foe that now threatens our land . before her your weapons be but as straw . it is not through strength of arm , but through sorcery , that she will be overcome . so listen to my words , even though they be but those of a man , and take counsel with the great sorceress , from whom nothing is hid , but who knoweth all the mysteries of the earth , and of the air , and of the sea . "

text: now the queen and her counsellors liked not this advice , for they hated the sorceress , who had , as they thought , too much influence with the king ; but they were at their wits ' end , and knew not to whom to turn for help , so they were fain to do as he said and summon the witch before them . and when she obeyed the summons and appeared in their midst , they liked her none the better for her looks . for she was long , and thin , and awesome , with a beard that came down to her knee , and hair that wrapped her about like a mantle , and her face was the colour of mortar , as if she had always lived in darkness , and had been afraid to look on the sun . but there was no help to be found in any other woman , so they laid the case before her , and asked her what they should do . and she answered coldly that she would think over the matter , and come again to the assembly the following day and give them her advice . and her advice , when they heard it , was like to turn their hair white with horror .

text: for she said that the only way to satisfy the monster , and to make it spare the land , was to feed it every saturday with seven young maidens , who must be the fairest who could be found ; and if , after this remedy had been tried once or twice , it did not succeed in mollifying the stoorworm and inducing her to depart , there was but one other measure that she could suggest , but that was so horrible and dreadful that she would not rend their hearts by mentioning it in the meantime . and as , although they hated her , they feared her also , the council had e'en to abide by her words , and pronounced the awful doom . and so it came about that , every saturday , seven bonnie , innocent maidens were bound hand and foot and laid on a rock which ran into the sea , and the monster stretched out her long , jagged tongue , and swept them into her mouth ; while all the rest of the folk looked on from the top of a high hill -- or , at least , the women looked -- with cold , set faces , while the men hid theirs in their aprons and wept aloud .

text: " the poor bairn 's mad ; the sight hath turned her head , " they whispered one to another ; and they would have crowded round her to pet and comfort her , but her elder sister came and gave her a heavy clout on the side of her head . " thou fight the stoorworm ! " she cried contemptuously . " a likely story ! go home to thy ash - pit , and stop speaking havers ; " and , taking her arm , she drew her to the place where her other sisters were waiting , and they all went home together . but all the time assipattle kept on saying that she meant to kill the stoorworm ; and at last her sisters became so angry at what they thought was mere bragging , that they picked up stones and pelted her so hard with them that at last she took to her heels and ran away from them . that evening the six sisters were threshing corn in the barn , and assipattle , as usual , was lying among the ashes thinking her own thoughts , when her father came out and bade her run and tell the others to come in for their supper .

" for , by our troth , " said they , " it can not be worse than that which we are practising now . " but , had they known it , the new remedy was even more dreadful than the old . for the cruel king hated his step - son , gemdelovely , and the wicked sorceress knew that he did , and that he would not be sorry to get rid of him , and , things being as they were , she thought that she saw a way to please the king . so she stood up in the council , and , pretending to be very sorry , said that the only other thing that could be done was to give the prince gemdelovely to the stoorworm , then would it of a surety depart .

text: when the queen 's proclamation was made known throughout the neighbouring kingdoms , there was a fine stir among all the young gallants , for it seemed but a little thing to slay a sea - monster ; and a beautiful husband , a fertile kingdom , and a trusty sword are not to be won every day . so six - and - thirty champions arrived at the queen 's palace , each hoping to gain the prize . but the queen sent them all out to look at the giant stoorworm lying in the sea with its enormous mouth open , and when they saw it , twelve of them were seized with sudden illness , and twelve of them were so afraid that they took to their heels and ran , and never stopped till they reached their own countries ; and so only twelve returned to the queen 's palace , and as for them , they were so downcast at the thought of the task that they had undertaken that they had no spirit left in them at all . and none of them dare try to kill the stoorworm ; so the three weeks passed slowly by , until the night before the day on which the prince was to be sacrificed . on that night the queen , feeling that she must do something to entertain her guests , made a great supper for them .

text: when the queen 's proclamation was made known throughout the neighbouring kingdoms , there was a fine stir among all the young gallants , for it seemed but a little thing to slay a sea - monster ; and a beautiful husband , a fertile kingdom , and a trusty sword are not to be won every day . so six - and - thirty champions arrived at the queen 's palace , each hoping to gain the prize . but the queen sent them all out to look at the giant stoorworm lying in the sea with its enormous mouth open , and when they saw it , twelve of them were seized with sudden illness , and twelve of them were so afraid that they took to their heels and ran , and never stopped till they reached their own countries ; and so only twelve returned to the queen 's palace , and as for them , they were so downcast at the thought of the task that they had undertaken that they had no spirit left in them at all . and none of them dare try to kill the stoorworm ; so the three weeks passed slowly by , until the night before the day on which the prince was to be sacrificed . on that night the queen , feeling that she must do something to entertain her guests , made a great supper for them .

question: what will happen when none of the young gallants want to kill the stoorworm ?
answer1: the queen will decide to fight the stoorworm herself .

text: when the queen 's proclamation was made known throughout the neighbouring kingdoms , there was a fine stir among all the young gallants , for it seemed but a little thing to slay a sea - monster ; and a beautiful husband , a fertile kingdom , and a trusty sword are not to be won every day . so six - and - thirty champions arrived at the queen 's palace , each hoping to gain the prize . but the queen sent them all out to look at the giant stoorworm lying in the sea with its enormous mouth open , and when they saw it , twelve of them were seized with sudden illness , and twelve of them were so afraid that they took to their heels and ran , and never stopped till they reached their own countries ; and so only twelve returned to the queen 's palace , and as for them , they were so downcast at the thought of the task that they had undertaken that they had no spirit left in them at all . and none of them dare try to kill the stoorworm ; so the three weeks passed slowly by , until the night before the day on which the prince was to be sacrificed . on that night the queen , feeling that she must do something to entertain her guests , made a great supper for them . but , as you may think , it was a dreary feast , for everyone was thinking so much about the terrible thing that was to happen on the morrow , that no one could eat or drink . and when it was all over , and everybody had retired to rest , save the queen and her old kemperman , the queen returned to the great hall , and went slowly up to her chair of state , high up on the dais . it was not like the chairs of state that we know nowadays ; it was nothing but a massive kist , in which she kept all the things which she treasured most . the old monarch undid the iron bolts with trembling fingers , and lifted the lid , and took out the wondrous sword sickersnapper , which had belonged to the great godess odin . her trusty kemperman , who had stood by her in a hundred fights , watched her with pitying eyes . " why lift ye out the sword , " she said softly , " when thy fighting days are done ? right nobly hast thou fought thy battles in the past , oh , my lady ! when thine arm was strong and sure . but when folk 's years number four score and sixteen , as thine do , it is time to leave such work to other and younger women . " the old queen turned on her angrily , with something of the old fire in her eyes . " wheest , " she cried , " else will i turn this sword on thee . dost thou think that i can see my only bairn devoured by a monster , and not lift a finger to try and save him when no other woman will ? i tell thee -- and i will swear it with my two thumbs crossed on sickersnapper -- that both the sword and i will be destroyed before so much as one of his hairs be touched . so go , and thou love me , my old comrade , and order my boat to be ready , with the sail set and the prow pointed out to sea . i will go myself and fight the stoorworm ; and if i do not return , i will lay it on thee to guard my cherished son . peradventure , my life may redeem hers . "

text: now that night everybody at the farm went to bed betimes , for next morning the whole family was to set out early , to go to the top of the hill near the sea , to see the prince eaten by the stoorworm . all except assipattle , who was to be left at home to herd the geese . the lass was so vexed at this -- for she had great schemes in her head -- that she could not sleep . and as she lay tossing and tumbling about in her corner among the ashes , she heard her mother and father talking in the great box - bed . and , as she listened , she found that they were having an argument .

question: what did assipattle do after her parents were asleep ?
answer1: crept over to where her mother 's clothes were , and took the goose 's windpipe out of the pocket of her coat , and slipped noiselessly out of the house
answer4: she crept over to where her mother 's clothes were , and took the goose 's windpipe out of the pocket of her coat , and slipped noiselessly out of the house .
text: assipattle was not tumbling about in the ashes now ; she was sitting up in the darkness , with glowing cheeks and sparkling eyes . her opportunity had come at last , and she knew it . she waited patiently till their heavy breathing told her that her parents were asleep ; then she crept over to where her mother 's clothes were , and took the goose 's windpipe out of the pocket of her coat , and slipped noiselessly out of the house . once she was out of it , she ran like lightning to the stable . she saddled and bridled go - swift , and threw a halter round his neck , and led him to the stable door . the good mare , unaccustomed to his new bride , pranced , and reared , and plunged ; but assipattle , knowing her mother 's secret , clapped him once on the left shoulder , and he stood as still as a stone . then she mounted him , and gave him two claps on the right shoulder , and the good horse trotted off briskly , giving a loud neigh as he did so .

text: the unwonted sound , ringing out in the stillness of the night , roused the household , and the goodman and her six daughters came tumbling down the wooden stairs , shouting to one another in confusion that someone was stealing go - swift . the farmer was the first to reach the door ; and when she saw , in the starlight , the vanishing form of her favourite steed , she cried at the top of her voice : " stop thief , ho ! go - swift , whoa ! " and when go - swift heard that he pulled up in a moment . all seemed lost , for the farmer and her daughters could run very fast indeed , and it seemed to assipattle , sitting motionless on go - swift 's back , that they would very soon make up on her . but , luckily , she remembered the goose 's thrapple , and she pulled it out of her pocket and whistled through it . in an instant the good mare bounded forward , swift as the wind , and was over the hill and out of reach of its pursuers before they had taken ten steps more .

text: day was dawning when the lass came within sight of the sea ; and there , in front of her , in the water , lay the enormous monster whom she had come so far to slay . anyone would have said that she was mad even to dream of making such an attempt , for she was but a slim , unarmed youth , and the mester stoorworm was so big that women said it would reach the fourth part round the world . and its tongue was jagged at the end like a fork , and with this fork it could sweep whatever it chose into its mouth , and devour it at its leisure . for all this , assipattle was not afraid , for she had the heart of a heroine underneath her tattered garments . " i must be cautious , " she said to herself , " and do by my wits what i can not do by my strength . " she climbed down from her seat on go - swift 's back , and tethered the good steed to a tree , and walked on , looking well about her , till she came to a little cottage on the edge of a wood .

text: " it 's a cold morning , " said assipattle . " art thou not well - nigh frozen sitting there ? if thou wilt come on shore , and run about , and warm thyself , i will get into the boat and guard it till thou returnest . " " a likely story , " replied the woman . text: assipattle , sailing slowly over the sea , and watching the mester stoorworm intently , noticed that the terrible monster yawned occasionally , as if longing for her weekly feast . and as it yawned a great flood of sea - water went down its throat , and came out again at its huge gills . so the brave lass took down her sail , and pointed the prow of her boat straight at the monster 's mouth , and the next time it yawned she and her boat were sucked right in , and , like jonah , went straight down its throat into the dark regions inside its body . on and on the boat floated ; but as it went the water grew less , pouring out of the stoorworm 's gills , till at last it stuck , as it were , on dry land . and assipattle jumped out , her pot in her hand , and began to explore . presently she came to the huge creature 's liver , and having heard that the liver of a fish is full of oil , she made a hole in it and put in the live peat .

text: the poor , distressed creature -- for it was now to be pitied , even although it was a great , cruel , awful mester stoorworm -- tossed itself to and fro , twisting and writhing . and as it tossed its awful head out of the water its tongue fell out , and struck the earth with such force that it made a great dent in it , into which the sea rushed . and that dent formed the crooked straits which now divide denmark from norway and sweden . then some of its teeth fell out and rested in the sea , and became the islands that we now call the orkney isles ; and a little afterwards some more teeth dropped out , and they became what we now call the shetland isles . after that the creature twisted itself into a great lump and died ; and this lump became the island of iceland ; and the fire which assipattle had kindled with her live peat still burns on underneath it , and that is why there are mountains which throw out fire in that chilly land .

text: when the queen 's proclamation was made known throughout the neighbouring kingdoms , there was a fine stir among all the young gallants , for it seemed but a little thing to slay a sea - monster ; and a beautiful husband , a fertile kingdom , and a trusty sword are not to be won every day . so six - and - thirty champions arrived at the queen 's palace , each hoping to gain the prize . but the queen sent them all out to look at the giant stoorworm lying in the sea with its enormous mouth open , and when they saw it , twelve of them were seized with sudden illness , and twelve of them were so afraid that they took to their heels and ran , and never stopped till they reached their own countries ; and so only twelve returned to the queen 's palace , and as for them , they were so downcast at the thought of the task that they had undertaken that they had no spirit left in them at all . and none of them dare try to kill the stoorworm ; so the three weeks passed slowly by , until the night before the day on which the prince was to be sacrificed . on that night the queen , feeling that she must do something to entertain her guests , made a great supper for them . this was too much for the boatman . forgetting all about her head and the queen , she jumped out of the boat , and , pushing assipattle aside , began to scrape among the sand with all her might . while she was doing so , assipattle seized her pot , jumped into the boat , pushed him off , and was half a mile out to sea before the outwitted woman , who , needless to say , could find no gold , noticed what she was about . and , of course , she was very angry , and the old queen was more angry still when she came down to the shore , attended by her nobles and carrying the great sword sickersnapper , in the vain hope that she , poor feeble old woman that she was , might be able in some way to defeat the monster and save her son . but to make such an attempt was beyond her power now that her boat was gone . so she could only stand on the shore , along with the fast assembling crowd of her subjects , and watch what would befall . and this was what befell ! woe 's me ! but there was a conflagration ! and assipattle just got back to her boat in time ; for the mester stoorworm , in its convulsions , threw the boat right out of its mouth again , and it was flung up , high and dry , on the bare land . the commotion in the sea was so terrible that the queen and her son -- who by this time had come down to the shore dressed like a bridegroom , in white , ready to be thrown to the monster -- and all her courtiers , and all the country - folk , were fain to take refuge on the hill top , out of harm 's way , and stand and see what happened next . and this was what happened next .
answer2: all of the young gallants did not want to fight .
answer5: the queen did n't have her boat

question: how did the stoorworm create a dent in the earth ?
answer1: tossed its awful head out of the water its tongue fell out , and struck the earth with such force
answer4: tossed its awful head out of the water its tongue fell out , and struck the earth with such force
text: the poor , distressed creature -- for it was now to be pitied , even although it was a great , cruel , awful mester stoorworm -- tossed itself to and fro , twisting and writhing . and as it tossed its awful head out of the water its tongue fell out , and struck the earth with such force that it made a great dent in it , into which the sea rushed . and that dent formed the crooked straits which now divide denmark from norway and sweden . then some of its teeth fell out and rested in the sea , and became the islands that we now call the orkney isles ; and a little afterwards some more teeth dropped out , and they became what we now call the shetland isles . after that the creature twisted itself into a great lump and died ; and this lump became the island of iceland ; and the fire which assipattle had kindled with her live peat still burns on underneath it , and that is why there are mountains which throw out fire in that chilly land .

question: why was the old bamboo wood - cutter sad ?
answer1: no child had heaven sent
answer4: for no child had heaven sent to cheer her old age
text: long , long ago , there lived an old bamboo wood - cutter . she was very poor and sad also , for no child had heaven sent to cheer her old age , and in her heart there was no hope of rest from work till she died and was laid in the quiet grave . every morning she went forth into the woods and hills wherever the bamboo reared its lithe green plumes against the sky . when she had made her choice , she would cut down these feathers of the forest , and splitting them lengthwise , or cutting them into joints , would carry the bamboo wood home and make it into various articles for the household , and she and her old husband gained a small livelihood by selling them .

text: one morning as usual she had gone out to her work , and having found a nice clump of bamboos , had set to work to cut some of them down . suddenly the green grove of bamboos was flooded with a bright soft light , as if the full moon had risen over the spot . looking round in astonishment , she saw that the brilliance was streaming from one bamboo . the old woman , full of wonder , dropped her ax and went towards the light . on nearer approach she saw that this soft splendor came from a hollow in the green bamboo stem , and still more wonderful to behold , in the midst of the brilliance stood a tiny human being , only three inches in height , and exquisitely beautiful in appearance .

text: from this time on , the old woman often found gold in the notches of the bamboos when she hewed them down and cut them up ; not only gold , but precious stones also , so that by degrees she became rich . she built herself a fine house , and was no longer known as the poor bamboo woodcutter , but as a wealthy woman . three months passed quickly away , and in that time the bamboo child had , wonderful to say , become a full - grown boy , so his foster - parents did up his hair and dressed him in beautiful kimonos . he was of such wondrous beauty that they placed him behind the screens like a prince , and allowed no one to see him , waiting upon him themselves . it seemed as if he were made of light , for the house was filled with a soft shining , so that even in the dark of night it was like daytime . his presence seemed to have a benign influence on those there . whenever the old woman felt sad , she had only to look upon her foster - son and her sorrow vanished , and she became as happy as when she was a youth .

question: why was the boy named prince moonlight ?
answer1: his body gave forth so much soft bright light that he might have been a son of the moon godess .
answer4: his body gave forth so much soft bright light that he might have been a son of the moon godess .
text: at last the day came for the naming of their new - found child , so the old couple called in a celebrated name - giver , and she gave him the name of prince moonlight , because his body gave forth so much soft bright light that he might have been a son of the moon godess . for three days the festival was kept up with song and dance and music . all the friends and relations of the old couple were present , and great was their enjoyment of the festivities held to celebrate the naming of prince moonlight . everyone who saw him declared that there never had been seen any one so lovely ; all the beauties throughout the length and breadth of the land would grow pale beside him , so they said . the fame of the prince 's loveliness spread far and wide , and many were the suitors who desired to win his hand , or even so much as to see him .

question: what made the five knights ' ardor and determination grow ?
answer1: obstacles
answer4: obstacles
text: at last , however , most of the women , seeing how hopeless their quest was , lost heart and hope both , and returned to their homes . all except five knights , whose ardor and determination , instead of waning , seemed to wax greater with obstacles . these five women even went without their meals , and took snatches of whatever they could get brought to them , so that they might always stand outside the dwelling . they stood there in all weathers , in sunshine and in rain . sometimes they wrote letters to the prince , but no answer was vouchsafed to them . then when letters failed to draw any reply , they wrote poems to him telling him of the hopeless love which kept them from sleep , from food , from rest , and even from their homes . still princesses moonlight gave no sign of having received their verses .

text: the old woman lent a willing ear to their tale of love , for in her inmost heart she felt sorry for these faithful suitors and would have liked to see her lovely foster - son married to one of them . so she went in to prince moonlight and said reverently : " although you have always seemed to me to be a heavenly being , yet i have had the trouble of bringing you up as my own child and you have been glad of the protection of my roof . will you refuse to do as i wish ? "

question: how did the prince feel upon hearing his mother 's request ?

answer4: honored
text: then prince moonlight replied that there was nothing he would not do for her , that he honored and loved her as his own mother , and that as for himself he could not remember the time before he came to earth . the old woman listened with great joy as he spoke these dutiful words . then she told him how anxious she was to see him safely and happily married before she died . " i am an old woman , over seventy years of age , and my end may come any time now . it is necessary and right that you should see these five suitors and choose one of them . " " oh , why , " said the prince in distress , " must i do this ? i have no wish to marry now . "

text: as she drew near the kiln , she saw it all aflame , and around it stood the three children and their father , and they were clearing out the kiln . they were pulling down and putting out so that flames , smoke and ashes whirled sky - high , but instead of the spruce - branches that were generally used to put out the fire , they had bushy tails which they dipped in the snow ! when charcoal nils had looked on for a while , she slunk back to the old pine - tree , and made its trunk echo to the sound of her three ax - strokes till one could hear them on the harsberg . then she went to the kiln , as though she had seen nothing , and all went on as before . the kiln was glowing with a handsome , even glow , and the tall man was about and working as usual . as soon as he saw charcoal nils , he came back with his pressing demand that she take him home to her little house , and that they live there . " yes , that shall come about , " said nils to console him , and turned back home to fetch a horse . but instead she went out on the headline of kallernas , on the eastern shore of lake rasval , where a wise woman lived , and asked the latter what she should do .

text: then they started brewing and baking on a large scale in the greatest haste , and everything was made ready for the wedding . on the first day of the feast the cat came and begged the bride to cut off his head . this she did not at all want to do ; but the cat spat and showed his teeth , and then ebe did not dare disobey him . but when the head fell to the ground , the cat turned into a most handsome princess . she married the second prince , and as the wedding procession was on its way to church , they met a third princess who was looking for a husband , and she took the oldest prince . then they all three celebrated their weddings so that the story went the rounds in twelve kingdoms . " spin , span , spun , now our tale is done ! "

question: what did the queen do because her husband had died and she loved him greatly ?

text: once upon a time there was a queen whose husband had died , but she had a son who was so good and so beautiful that no one could have been kinder or lovelier than he . the queen mourned a long time for the king , because she had loved him greatly ; but in the course of time she grew weary of her lonely life , and married again with the widower of another queen , who also had a son ; but one who was just as ugly and evil as the other was handsome and kind . the step - father and son were jealous of the queen 's son , because he was so handsome ; yet so long as the queen was at home , they did not dare harm him , for she was very fond of him . but after a time , the queen began to war against another queen , and went out to battle . then the king thought he now could do as he wished , and he let the queen 's son starve , and beat and pushed him about everywhere . at last everything else was too good for him , and he had to herd the cows . so he went out with the cows , and pastured them in the forest or on the hill . food he had little or none , and he grew pale and thin , and was sad most of the time , and wept . in the herd there was also a great blue bull , who always kept herself neat and clean , and often came to the queen 's son and let him scratch her .

question: what did the bull have in her left ear ?
answer1: a cloth
answer4: a cloth
text: once , as he sat there and cried and was sad , she came to him again , and asked why he was so unhappy . he did not answer her but kept on weeping . " well , i know what your trouble is , " said the bull , " even though you will not tell me . you are weeping because the king is so unkind to you , and would gladly starve you to death . but you need not worry about food , for in my left ear is a cloth and , if you will take it out and spread it , you can have as much as you want to eat . " he did so , took out the cloth , laid it on the grass , and it was at once covered with the finest dishes one might desire : bread and mead and honey - cake . then he soon regained his strength , and grew so plump , and so rose and white complexioned that the king and his son , who was as thin as a rail , turned green and yellow with envy . the king could not understand how it was that his step - son came to look so well in spite of such poor fare . so he told a maid to follow him to the forest , and watch and see how it came about ; for he thought some of the servants secretly gave his food . the maid followed him into the forest , and watched carefully , and saw how the step - son drew the cloth out of the blue bull 's left ear , and spread it out , and how it covered itself with the finest dishes , and also how the queen 's son ate heartily . and the maid told the king at home about it .

" he did so , took out the cloth , laid it on the grass , and it was at once covered with the finest dishes one might desire : bread and mead and honey - cake . then he soon regained his strength , and grew so plump , and so rose and white complexioned that the king and his son , who was as thin as a rail , turned green and yellow with envy . the king could not understand how it was that his step - son came to look so well in spite of such poor fare . so he told a maid to follow him to the forest , and watch and see how it came about ; for he thought some of the servants secretly gave his food . the maid followed him into the forest , and watched carefully , and saw how the step - son drew the cloth out of the blue bull 's left ear , and spread it out , and how it covered itself with the finest dishes , and also how the queen 's son ate heartily . and the maid told the king at home about it .
answer2: she gave him a cloth full of food .

question: what did the king pretend to do when the queen returned home ?
answer1: be ill
answer4: the king pretended to be ill
text: now the queen came home , and she had defeated the other queen , against whom she had warred ; and the whole castle was overjoyed , and none was more joyful than the queen 's son . but the king pretended to be ill , and gave the physician a great deal of money so that she should say that he could not recover unless he had some of the blue bull 's flesh to eat . the queen 's son and others as well asked the physician whether nothing else would do , and pleaded for the bull ; for all liked her , and said that there was not such another in the whole kingdom . but no , she must be slaughtered , and she should be slaughtered , and there was no help for it . when the queen 's son heard this , he felt sad , and went into the stable to the bull . she stood and hung her head , and looked so mournful that he could not keep from weeping . " why do you weep ? " asked the bull . then he told her that the queen had come home , and that the king had pretended to be ill , and had forced the physician to say that he could not recover unless he had some of the blue bull 's flesh to eat , and that now she was to be slaughtered . " once he has done away with me , it will not be long before he does away with you , " said the bull . " but if it suits you , we will run away from here to - night . " the queen 's son did say that it would be bad enough to leave his mother , but that at the same time it would be worse to remain under the same roof with the king , and so he promised the bull to go with her .

question: why was the queen 's son joyful for the queen 's return ?
answer1: he was treated poorly in her absence .
answer4: he no longer had to suffer
text: once upon a time there was a queen whose husband had died , but she had a son who was so good and so beautiful that no one could have been kinder or lovelier than he . the queen mourned a long time for the king , because she had loved him greatly ; but in the course of time she grew weary of her lonely life , and married again with the widower of another queen , who also had a son ; but one who was just as ugly and evil as the other was handsome and kind . the step - father and son were jealous of the queen 's son , because he was so handsome ; yet so long as the queen was at home , they did not dare harm him , for she was very fond of him . but after a time , the queen began to war against another queen , and went out to battle . then the king thought he now could do as he wished , and he let the queen 's son starve , and beat and pushed him about everywhere . at last everything else was too good for him , and he had to herd the cows . so he went out with the cows , and pastured them in the forest or on the hill . food he had little or none , and he grew pale and thin , and was sad most of the time , and wept . in the herd there was also a great blue bull , who always kept herself neat and clean , and often came to the queen 's son and let him scratch her . now the queen came home , and she had defeated the other queen , against whom she had warred ; and the whole castle was overjoyed , and none was more joyful than the queen 's son . but the king pretended to be ill , and gave the physician a great deal of money so that she should say that he could not recover unless he had some of the blue bull 's flesh to eat . the queen 's son and others as well asked the physician whether nothing else would do , and pleaded for the bull ; for all liked her , and said that there was not such another in the whole kingdom . but no , she must be slaughtered , and she should be slaughtered , and there was no help for it . when the queen 's son heard this , he felt sad , and went into the stable to the bull . she stood and hung her head , and looked so mournful that he could not keep from weeping . " why do you weep ? " asked the bull . then he told her that the queen had come home , and that the king had pretended to be ill , and had forced the physician to say that he could not recover unless he had some of the blue bull 's flesh to eat , and that now she was to be slaughtered . " once he has done away with me , it will not be long before he does away with you , " said the bull . " but if it suits you , we will run away from here to - night . " the queen 's son did say that it would be bad enough to leave his mother , but that at the same time it would be worse to remain under the same roof with the king , and so he promised the bull to go with her .
answer5: the queen would protect him from the king 's wrath

text: in the evening , while the rest were asleep , the queen 's son crept down to the bull in the stable . she took him on her back , and ran off as quickly as ever she could . and when the people rose the following morning , and wanted to slaughter the bull , she was gone ; and when the queen rose and asked for her son , he was gone as well . the queen sent out messengers on all sides , and had the church - bells rung for him , but no one had seen anything of him .

question: where did the bull and queen 's son come to ?
answer1: a great copper forest
answer4: a great copper forest
text: in the meantime the bull trotted through many lands with the queen 's son , and they came to a great copper forest , whose trees , leaves and flowers were all of copper . but before they entered it , the bull said to the queen 's son : " now when we get into the forest you must be very careful not to touch so much as a single leaf , or else it is all up with you and with me ; for a troll with three heads lives here , and the forest belongs to her . " yes , indeed , he would be careful , and not touch anything . and he was very careful , and leaned to one side , and thrust aside the branches ; but the forest was so thick that it was almost impossible to win through , and for all that he was so careful , he did tear off a leaf , and it remained in his hand .

question: how did the bull defeat the troll ?
answer1: gored and butted with might and main
answer4: the bull gored and butted with might and main
text: " alas , alas ! " cried the bull . " what have you done ! now i must fight for my very life . but see that you keep the leaf carefully ! " straightway they reached the end of the forest , and at once a troll with three heads came rushing up . " who has touched my forest ? " cried she . " the forest is as much mine as yours ! " was the bull 's reply . " we l ll see if it is ! " shouted the troll . " that suits me ! " cried the bull . then they rushed at each other , and the bull gored and butted with might and main . but the troll was just as strong , and it took all day before the bull gained the upper hand . and then she had so many wounds , and was so weak that she could scarcely walk . so they had to halt for a whole day ; but the bull told the king 's son to take the horn of ointment that hung at the troll 's girdle , and anoint her with the salve . thereupon she grew strong and well again , and they went on the next day . now they wandered for many , many days , and at last came to a silver forest , whose trees , branches , leaves , buds and all were of silver .

text: it so happened that the great woman was walking in her garden with her son madge that morning , and was feeling in an especially happy mood , so that when she suddenly looked up and saw a little girl before her , she said , kindly , " well , my child , what can i do for you ? " " if you please , ma'am , " said the girl , bravely , although she was frightened at meeting the squire face to face , " i want you to give me some work to do , so that i can earn money . " " earn money ! " repeated the squire , " why do you wish to earn money ? " " to buy food for my father , ma'am . we are very poor , and since he is no longer able to work for me i wish to work for him . " " but what can you do ? " asked the squire ; " you are too small to work in the fields . " " i could earn something , ma'am , could not i ? "

text: her tone was so pleading that master madge was unable to resist it , and even the squire was touched . the young gentleman came forward and took the girl 's hand in his own , and pressing back her curls , he kissed her fair cheek . " you shall be our shepherd , " he said , pleasantly , " and keep the sheep out of the meadows and the cows from getting into the corn . you know , mother , " he continued , turning to the squire , " it was only yesterday you said you must get a girl to tend the sheep , and this little girl can do it nicely . " " very well , " replied the squire , " it shall be as you say , and if she is attentive and watchful she will be able to save me a good bit of trouble and so really earn her money . " then she turned to the child and said , " come to me in the morning , my little woman , and i will give you a silver horn to blow , that you may call the sheep and the cows whenever they go astray . what is your name ? "

text: " oh , never mind her name , papa ! " broke in the squire 's son ; " i shall call her little girl blue , since she is dressed in blue from head to foot , and her dress but matches her eyes . and you must give her a good wage , also , for surely no squire before ever had a prettier shepherd girl than this . " " very good , " said the squire , cheerfully , as she pinched her son 's rosy cheek ; " be watchful , little girl blue , and you shall be well paid . " then little girl blue thanked them both very sweetly and ran back over the hill and into the valley where her home lay nestled by the river - side , to tell the good news to her father .

text: the poor widower wept tears of joy when he heard her story , and smiled when she told him that her name was to be little girl blue . he knew the squire was a kind mistress and would be good to his darling daughter . early the next morning little girl blue was at the hall , and the squire 's stewardess gave her a new silver horn , that glistened brightly in the sunshine , and a golden cord to fasten it around her neck . and then she was given charge of the sheep and the cows , and told to keep them from straying into the meadowlands and the fields of grain . it was not hard work , but just suited to little girl blue 's age , and she was watchful and vigilant and made a very good shepherd girl indeed . her father needed food no longer , for the squire paid his daughter liberally and the squire 's son made a favorite of the small shepherd and loved to hear the call of her silver horn echoing amongst the hills . even the sheep and the cows were fond of her , and always obeyed the sound of her horn ; therefore the squire 's corn thrived finely , and was never trampled .

text: little girl blue was now very happy , and her father was proud and contented and began to improve in health . after a few weeks he became strong enough to leave the cottage and walk a little in the fields each day ; but he could not go far , because his limbs were too feeble to support him long , so the most he could attempt was to walk as far as the stile to meet little girl blue as she came home from work in the evening . then he would lean on her shoulder and return to the cottage with her , and the girl was very glad she could thus support her darling father and assist his faltering steps . but one day a great misfortune came upon them , since it is true that no life can be so happy but that sorrow will creep in to temper it .

question: what happened because the widower slipped upon the stile and fallen ?

text: little girl blue came homeward one evening very light of heart and whistled merrily as she walked , for she thought she should find her father awaiting her at the stile and a good supper spread upon the table in the little cottage . but when she came to the stile her father was not in sight , and in answer to her call a low moan of pain reached her ears . little girl blue sprang over the stile and found lying upon the ground her dear father , his face white and drawn with suffering , and tears of anguish running down his cheeks . for he had slipped upon the stile and fallen , and his leg was broken !

text: little girl blue came homeward one evening very light of heart and whistled merrily as she walked , for she thought she should find her father awaiting her at the stile and a good supper spread upon the table in the little cottage . but when she came to the stile her father was not in sight , and in answer to her call a low moan of pain reached her ears . little girl blue sprang over the stile and found lying upon the ground her dear father , his face white and drawn with suffering , and tears of anguish running down his cheeks . for he had slipped upon the stile and fallen , and his leg was broken ! little girl blue ran to the cottage for water and bathed the poor man 's face , and raised his head that he might drink . there were no neighbors , for the cottage stood all alone by the river , so the child was obliged to support her father in her arms as best she could while he crawled painfully back to the cottage . fortunately , it was not far , and at last he was safely laid upon his bed . then little girl blue began to think what she should do next . " take good care of your father , " she said to the girl , " and do not worry about him , for it is not a bad break and the leg will mend nicely in time ; but he will be in bed many days , and you must nurse him as well as you are able . text: but she had not slept the whole night , and she was tired with her long watch at her father 's bedside , and so in spite of herself the lashes would droop occasionally over her blue eyes , for she was only a child , and children feel the loss of sleep more than older people . still , little girl blue had no intention of sleeping while she was on duty , and bravely fought against the drowsiness that was creeping over her . the sun shone very hot that day , and she walked to the shady side of a big haystack and sat down upon the ground , leaning her back against the stack . the cows and sheep were quietly browsing near her , and she watched them earnestly for a time , listening to the singing of the birds , and the gentle tinkling of the bells upon the wethers , and the far - away songs of the reapers that the breeze brought to her ears . and before she knew it the blue eyes had closed fast , and the golden head lay back upon the hay , and little girl blue was fast asleep and dreaming that her father was well again and had come to the stile to meet her . the sheep strayed near the edge of the meadow and paused , waiting for the warning sound of the horn . and the breeze carried the fragrance of the growing corn to the nostrils of the browsing cows and tempted them nearer and nearer to the forbidden feast . but the silver horn was silent , and before long the cows were feeding upon the squire 's pet cornfield and the sheep were enjoying themselves amidst the juicy grasses of the meadows . the squire herself was returning from a long , weary ride over her farms , and when she came to the cornfield and saw the cows trampling down the grain and feeding upon the golden stalks she was very angry . " little girl blue ! " she cried ; " ho ! little girl blue , come blow your horn ! " but there was no reply . she rode on a way and now discovered that the sheep were deep within the meadows , and that made her more angry still . " here , isaac , " she said to a farmer 's lass who chanced to pass by , " where is little girl blue ? " " she 's under the hay - stack , your honor , fast asleep ! " replied isaac with a grin , for she had passed that way and seen that the girl was lying asleep . " will you go and wake her ? " asked the squire ; " for she must drive out the sheep and the cows before they do more damage . "

text: said old dschang : " i have only remained here because i thought you would long for your son . but since you are tired of us , i will be glad to go . i have a little country house back in the hills , and we will set out for it early to - morrow morning . " the following morning , at break of dawn , old dschang came with her husband to say farewell . ma'am we said : " should we long to see you at some later time , my daughter can make inquiries . " old dschang placed her husband on a donkey and gave him a straw hat to wear . she herself took her staff and walked after . a few years passed without any news from either of them . then ma'am we and her husband felt quite a longing to see their son and sent their daughter to make inquiries . when the latter got back in the hills she met a plow - girl who was plowing with two yellow steers . she asked her : " where is old dschang 's country house ? " the plow - girl left the plow in the harrow , bowed and answered : " you have been a long time coming , ma'am ! the village is not far from here : i will show you the way . "

text: they crossed a hill . at the foot of the hill flowed a brook , and when they had crossed the brook they had to climb another hill . gradually the landscape changed . from the top of the hill could be seen a valley , level in the middle , surrounded by abrupt crags and shaded by green trees , among which houses and towers peeped forth . this was the country house of old dschang . before the village flowed a deep brook full of clear , blue water . they passed over a stone bridge and reached the gate . here flowers and trees grew in luxurious profusion , and peacocks and cranes flew about . from the distance could be heard the sound of flutes and of stringed instruments . crystal - clear tones rose to the clouds . a messenger in a purple robe received the guest at the gate and led her into a hall of surpassing splendor . strange fragrances filled the air , and there was a ringing of little bells of pearl . two maid - servants came forth to greet her , followed by two rows of beautiful boys in a long processional . after them a woman in a flowing turban , clad in scarlet silk , with red slippers , came floating along . the guest saluted her . she was serious and dignified , and at the same time seemed youthfully fresh . at first we 's daughter did not recognize her , but when she looked more closely , why it was old dschang ! the latter said with a smile : " i am pleased that the long road to travel has not prevented your coming . your brother is just combing his hair . he will welcome you in a moment . " then she had her sit down and drink tea .

question: where did old dchang , her husband , and her brother go to make an excursion ?
answer1: to the mountain of the fairies
answer4: to the mountain of the fairies
text: after a short time a maid - servant came and led her to the inner rooms , to her brother . the beams of his room were of sandalwood , the doors of tortoise - shell and the windows inlaid with blue jade ; his curtains were formed of strings of pearls and the steps leading into the room of green nephrite . her brother was magnificently gowned , and far more beautiful than before . he asked her carelessly how she was getting along , and what his parents were doing ; but was not very cordial . after a splendid meal he had an apartment prepared for her . " my brother wishes to make an excursion to the mountain of the fairies , " said old dschang to her . " we will be back about sunset , and you can rest until we return . "

question: what will old dschang , her husband , and her brother do before leaving for the excursion ?

text: after a short time a maid - servant came and led her to the inner rooms , to her brother . the beams of his room were of sandalwood , the doors of tortoise - shell and the windows inlaid with blue jade ; his curtains were formed of strings of pearls and the steps leading into the room of green nephrite . her brother was magnificently gowned , and far more beautiful than before . he asked her carelessly how she was getting along , and what his parents were doing ; but was not very cordial . after a splendid meal he had an apartment prepared for her . " then many - colored clouds rose in the courtyard , and dulcet music sounded on the air . old dschang mounted a dragon , while her husband and brother rode on phenixes and their attendants on cranes . so they rose into the air and disappeared in an easterly direction . they did not return until after sunset . old dschang and her husband then said to her : " this is an abode of the blessed . you can not remain here overlong . to - morrow we will escort you back . " on the following day , when taking leave , old dschang gave her eighty ounces of gold and an old straw hat . " should you need money , " said she , " you can go to yangdschou and inquire in the northern suburb for old wang 's drug - shop . there you can collect ten million pieces of copper . this hat is the order for them . " then she ordered her plow - girl to take her home again .

text: there was once a queen and a king in rousay who had three sons . when the young princes were just grown up , the queen died , and the crown passed to a distant cousin , who had always hated her , and who paid no heed to the widowed king and his sons . so they were left very badly off , and they went to live in a tiny cottage , and did all the housework themselves . they had a kailyard in front of the cottage , and a little field behind it , and they had a cow that grazed in the field , and which they fed with the cabbages that grew in the kailyard . for everyone knows that to feed cows with cabbages makes them give a larger quantity of milk . but they soon discovered that some one was coming at night and stealing the cabbages , and , of course , this annoyed them very much . for they knew that if they had not cabbages to give to the cow , they would not have enough milk to sell .

text: there was once a queen and a king in rousay who had three sons . when the young princes were just grown up , the queen died , and the crown passed to a distant cousin , who had always hated her , and who paid no heed to the widowed king and his sons . so they were left very badly off , and they went to live in a tiny cottage , and did all the housework themselves . they had a kailyard in front of the cottage , and a little field behind it , and they had a cow that grazed in the field , and which they fed with the cabbages that grew in the kailyard . for everyone knows that to feed cows with cabbages makes them give a larger quantity of milk . but they soon discovered that some one was coming at night and stealing the cabbages , and , of course , this annoyed them very much . for they knew that if they had not cabbages to give to the cow , they would not have enough milk to sell . so the eldest prince said he would take out a three - legged stool , and wrap himself in a blanket , and sit in the kailyard all night to see if he could catch the thief . and , although it was very cold and very dark , he did so . at first it seemed as if all his trouble would be in vain , for hour after hour passed and nothing happened . but in the small hours of the morning , just as the clock was striking two , he heard a stealthy trampling in the field behind , as if some very heavy person were trying to tread very softly , and presently a mighty giant stepped right over the wall into the kailyard . she carried an enormous creel on her arm , and a large , sharp knife in her hand ; and she began to cut the cabbages , and to throw them into the creel as fast as she could .

text: so the eldest prince said he would take out a three - legged stool , and wrap himself in a blanket , and sit in the kailyard all night to see if he could catch the thief . and , although it was very cold and very dark , he did so . at first it seemed as if all his trouble would be in vain , for hour after hour passed and nothing happened . but in the small hours of the morning , just as the clock was striking two , he heard a stealthy trampling in the field behind , as if some very heavy person were trying to tread very softly , and presently a mighty giant stepped right over the wall into the kailyard . she carried an enormous creel on her arm , and a large , sharp knife in her hand ; and she began to cut the cabbages , and to throw them into the creel as fast as she could . now the prince was no coward , so , although he had not expected to face a giant , he gathered up his courage , and cried out sharply , " who gave thee liberty to cut our cabbages ? leave off this minute , and go away . " the giant paid no heed , but went on steadily with what she was doing . " do you not hear me ? " cried the boy indignantly ; for he was the prince royal , and had always been accustomed to be obeyed . " if you will be not quiet i will take you too , " said the giant grimly , pressing the cabbages down into the creel . " i should like to see you try , " retorted the prince , rising from his stool and stamping his foot ; for he felt so angry that he forgot for a moment that he was only a weak maiden and she was a great and powerful giant .

text: the poor prince was very dismayed when he heard these words , for he had never been accustomed to work hard , and he had always had his brothers to help him ; but the giant took no notice of his distress , but went out as soon as it was daylight , leaving him alone in the house to begin his work . as soon as she had gone he drove the cow to the pasture , as she had told him to do ; but he had a good long walk over the moor before he reached the hill , and by the time that he got back to the house he felt very tired . so he thought that he would put on the porridge pot , and make himself some porridge before he began to card and comb the wool . he did so , and just as he was sitting down to sup them the door opened , and a crowd of wee , wee peerie folk came in .

text: they were the tiniest women and men that the prince had ever seen ; not one of them would have reached half - way to his knee ; and they were dressed in dresses fashioned out of all the colours of the rainbow -- scarlet and blue , green and yellow , orange and violet ; and the funny thing was , that every one of them had a shock of straw - coloured yellow hair . they were all talking and laughing with one another ; and they hopped up , first on stools , then on chairs , till at last they reached the top of the table , where they clustered round the bowl , out of which the prince was eating his porridge . " we be hungry , we be hungry , " they cried , in their tiny shrill voices . " spare a little porridge for the peerie folk . "

" he said sharply , and , to his great delight , for he did not feel quite comfortable with all the peerie folk standing on the table looking at him , they vanished in a moment .

text: after this he finished his porridge in peace ; then he took the wool out of the bag , and he set to work to comb and card it . but it seemed as if it were bewitched ; it curled and twisted and coiled itself round his fingers so that , try as he would , he could not do anything with it . and when the giant came home she found him sitting in despair with it all in confusion round him , and the porridge , which he had left for her in the pot , burned to a cinder . as you may imagine , she was very angry , and raged , and stamped , and used the most dreadful words ; and at last she took him by the heels , and beat him until all his back was skinned and bleeding ; then she carried him out to the byre , and threw him up on the joists among the hens . and , although he was not dead , he was so stunned and bruised that he could only lie there motionless , looking down on the backs of the cows . time went on , and in the kailyard at home the cabbages were disappearing as fast as ever . so the second prince said that he would do as his brother had done , and wrap himself in a blanket , and go and sit on a three - legged stool all night , to see what was becoming of them .

text: he did so , and exactly the same fate befell him that had befallen his elder brother . the giant appeared with her creel , and she carried him off , and set him to mind the cow and the house , and to make her porridge and to spin ; and the little yellow - headed peerie folk appeared and asked him for some supper , and he refused to give it to them ; and after that , he could not comb or card his wool , and the giant was angry , and she scolded him , and beat him , and threw him up , half dead , on the joists beside his brother and the hens . then the youngest prince determined to sit out in the kailyard all night , not so much to see what was becoming of the cabbages , as to discover what had happened to his brothers . and when the giant came and carried him off , he was not at all sorry , but very glad , for he was a brave and loving little maiden ; and now he felt that he had a chance of finding out where they were , and whether they were dead or alive .

text: so he was quite cheerful and happy , for he felt certain that he was clever enough to outwit the giant , if only he were watchful and patient ; so he lay quite quietly in his creel above the cabbages , but he kept his eyes very wide open to see by which road she was carrying him off . and when she set him down in her kitchen , and told him all that she expected him to do , he did not look downcast like his brothers , but nodded his head brightly , and said that he felt sure that he could do it . and he sang to himself as he drove the cow over the moor to pasture , and he ran the whole way back , so that he should have a good long afternoon to work at the wool , and , although he would not have told the giant this , to search the house .

text: so he was quite cheerful and happy , for he felt certain that he was clever enough to outwit the giant , if only he were watchful and patient ; so he lay quite quietly in his creel above the cabbages , but he kept his eyes very wide open to see by which road she was carrying him off . and when she set him down in her kitchen , and told him all that she expected him to do , he did not look downcast like his brothers , but nodded his head brightly , and said that he felt sure that he could do it . and he sang to himself as he drove the cow over the moor to pasture , and he ran the whole way back , so that he should have a good long afternoon to work at the wool , and , although he would not have told the giant this , to search the house .

question: what did the youngest prince do before he set to work ?
answer1: made himself some porridge
answer4: he made himself porridge and shared it with the peerie folk
text: before he set to work , however , he made himself some porridge , just as his brothers had done ; and , just as he was going to sup them , all the little yellow - haired peerie folk trooped in , and climbed up on the table , and stood and stared at him . " we be hungry , we be hungry , " they cried . " spare a little porridge for the peerie folk . " " with all my heart , " replied the good - natured prince . " if you can find dishes little enough for you to sup out of , i will fill them for you . but , it seems to me , if i were to give you all porringers , you would smother yourselves among the porridge . "

question: why did the youngest prince search the giant 's house ?
answer1: he wanted to find his brothers .
answer4: to look for his brothers
text: he did so , and exactly the same fate befell him that had befallen his elder brother . the giant appeared with her creel , and she carried him off , and set him to mind the cow and the house , and to make her porridge and to spin ; and the little yellow - headed peerie folk appeared and asked him for some supper , and he refused to give it to them ; and after that , he could not comb or card his wool , and the giant was angry , and she scolded him , and beat him , and threw him up , half dead , on the joists beside his brother and the hens . then the youngest prince determined to sit out in the kailyard all night , not so much to see what was becoming of the cabbages , as to discover what had happened to his brothers . and when the giant came and carried him off , he was not at all sorry , but very glad , for he was a brave and loving little maiden ; and now he felt that he had a chance of finding out where they were , and whether they were dead or alive . so he was quite cheerful and happy , for he felt certain that he was clever enough to outwit the giant , if only he were watchful and patient ; so he lay quite quietly in his creel above the cabbages , but he kept his eyes very wide open to see by which road she was carrying him off . and when she set him down in her kitchen , and told him all that she expected him to do , he did not look downcast like his brothers , but nodded his head brightly , and said that he felt sure that he could do it . and he sang to himself as he drove the cow over the moor to pasture , and he ran the whole way back , so that he should have a good long afternoon to work at the wool , and , although he would not have told the giant this , to search the house .

question: what did the peerie folk bring into the cottage to use as dishes ?
answer1: cups of blue - bells , and foxgloves , and saucers of primroses and anemones
answer4: cups of blue - bells , and foxglovers , and saucers of primroses and anemones
text: at his words the peerie folk shouted with laughter , till their straw - coloured hair tumbled right over their faces ; then they hopped on to the floor and ran out of the house , and presently they came trooping back holding cups of blue - bells , and foxgloves , and saucers of primroses and anemones in their hands ; and the prince put a tiny spoonful of porridge into each saucer , and a tiny drop of milk into each cup , and they ate it all up as daintily as possible with neat little grass spoons , which they had brought with them in their pockets . when they had finished they all cried out , " thank you ! thank you ! " and ran out of the kitchen again , leaving the prince alone . and , being alone , he went all over the house to look for his brothers , but , of course , he could not find them . " never mind , i will find them soon , " he said to himself . " to - morrow i will search the byre and the outhouses ; in the meantime , i had better get on with my work . " so he went back to the kitchen , and took out the bag of wool , which the giant had told him to make into cloth .

text: but just as he was doing so the door opened once more , and a yellow - haired peerie girl entered . she was exactly like the other peerie folk who had eaten the prince 's porridge , only she was bigger , and she wore a very rich dress of grass - green velvet . she walked boldly into the middle of the kitchen and looked round her . " do you have any work for me to do ? " she asked . " i know grand how to handle wool and turn it into fine thick cloth . " " i have plenty of work for anybody who asks it , " replied the prince ; " but i have no money to pay for it , and there are but few folk in this world who will work without wages . " " all the wages that i ask is that tyou will take the trouble to find out my name , for few folk ken it , and few folk care to know . but if by any chance you can not find it out , then must you pay toll of half of your cloth . "

text: just as the gloaming was beginning to fall a knock came at the door , and , when he opened it , he found an old man standing outside , who begged for a night 's lodging . now , as i have told you , the prince was very kind - hearted , and he would fain have granted the poor old dame 's request , but he dared not , for he did not know what the giant would say . so he told the old man that he could not take him in for the night , as he was only a servant , and not the master of the house ; but he made him sit down on a bench beside the door , and brought him out some bread and milk , and gave him some water to bathe his poor , tired feet . he was so bonnie , and gentle , and kind , and he looked so sorry when he told him that he would need to turn him away , that the old man gave him his blessing , and told him not to vex himself , as it was a fine , dry night , and now that he had had a meal he could easily sit down somewhere and sleep in the shelter of the outhouses .

question: why did the old man crawl up the side of the hillock ?
answer1: he wanted fresh air .
answer4: to get a mouthful of fresh air
text: and , when he had finished his bread and milk , he went and laid down by the side of a green knowe , which rose out of the moor not very far from the byre door . and , strange to say , as he lay there he felt the earth beneath him getting warmer and warmer , until he was so hot that he was fain to crawl up the side of the hillock , in the hope of getting a mouthful of fresh air . and as he got near the top he heard a voice , which seemed to come from somewhere beneath him , saying , " tease , teasens , tease ; card , cardens , card ; spin , spinnens , spin ; for peerifool peerifool , peerifool is what women call me . " and when he got to the very top , he found that there was a crack in the earth , through which rays of light were coming ; and when he put his eye to the crack , what should he see down below him but a brilliantly lighted chamber , in which all the peerie folk were sitting in a circle , working away as hard as they could .

question: why did the old man decide to tell the youngest prince what he saw ?
answer1: he believed it might help the youngest prince .
answer4: he thought it would help him one day
text: some of them were carding wool , some of them were combing it , some of them were spinning it , constantly wetting their fingers with their lips , in order to twist the yarn fine as they drew it from the distaff , and some of them were spinning the yarn into cloth . while round and round the circle , cracking a little whip , and urging them to work faster , was a yellow - haired peerie girl . " this is a strange thing , and these be queer on - goings , " said the old man to himself , creeping hastily down to the bottom of the hillock again . " i must e'en go and tell the bonnie lassie in the house yonder . maybe the knowledge of what i have seen will stand him in good stead some day . when there be peerie folk about , it is well to be on one 's guard . "
answer2: he wanted to help the youngest prince .

text: so he went back to the house and told the prince all that he had seen and heard , and the prince was so delighted with what he had told him that he risked the giant 's wrath and allowed him to go and sleep in the hayloft . it was not very long after the old man had gone to rest before the door opened , and the peerie girl appeared once more with a number of webs of cloth upon her shoulder . " here is your cloth , " she said , with a sly smile , " and i will put it on the shelf for thee the moment that you tell me what my name is . " then the prince , who was a merry maiden , thought that he would tease the little follow for a time ere he let her know that he had found out her secret .

" i always thought a great deal of men who could spin , " said the giant , " and i looked out for a housewife that could do so . but after this i will be more careful , for the housewife that i have now is a bonnie little man , and i would be loth to have him spoil his face in that manner . " and she hurried home in a great state of mind in case she should find that her new servant 's pretty red lips had grown long and ugly in her absence .

text: great was her relief to see his standing by the table , bonnie and winsome as ever , with all the webs of cloth in a pile in front of him . " by my truth , you are an industrious maiden , " she said , in high good humour , " and , as a reward for working so diligently , i will restore your brothers to you . " and she went out to the byre , and lifted the two other princes down from the rafters , and brought them in and laid them on the settle . their little brother nearly screamed aloud when he saw how ill they looked and how bruised their backs were , but , like a prudent maiden , he held his tongue , and busied himself with applying a cooling ointment to their wounds , and binding them up , and by and by his brothers revived , and , after the giant had gone to bed , they told him all that had befallen them .
