question: how did the youngest prince take revenge on the giant ?
answer1: he tricked her .
answer4: he stole all her belongings
text: " i will be avenged on her for her cruelty , " said the little prince firmly ; and when he spoke like that his brothers knew that he meant what he said . so next morning , before the giant was up , he fetched her creel , and put his eldest brother into it , and covered him with all the fine silken hangings and tapestry that he could find , and on the top of all he put a handful of grass , and when the giant came downstairs he asked her , in his sweetest tone , if she would do him a favour . and the giant , who was very pleased with him because of the quantity of cloth which she thought he had spun , said that she would . " then carry that creelful of grass home to my father 's cottage for his cow to eat , " said the prince . " this will help to make up for all the cabbages which you have stolen from his kailyard . " and , wonderful to relate , the giant did as she was bid , and carried the creel to the cottage . next morning he put his second brother into another creel , and covered him with all the fine napery he could find in the house , and put an armful of grass on the top of it , and at his bidding the giant , who was really getting very fond of him , carried it also home to his father . the next morning the little prince told her that he thought that he would go for a long walk after he had done his housework , and that he might not be in when she came home at night , but that he would have another creel of grass ready for her , if she would carry it to the cottage as she had done on the two previous evenings . she promised to do so ; then , as usual , she went out for the day . in the afternoon the clever little maiden went through the house , gathering together all the lace , and silver , and jewellery that he could find , and brought them and placed them beside the creel . then he went out and cut an armful of grass , and brought it in and laid it beside them . then he crept into the creel himself , and pulled all the fine things in above him , and then he covered everything up with the grass , which was a very difficult thing to do , seeing he himself was at the bottom of the basket . then he lay quite still and waited . presently the giant came in , and , obedient to her promise , she lifted the creel and carried it off to the old king 's cottage . no one seemed to be at home , so she set it down in the entry , and turned to go away . but the little prince had told his brothers what to do , and they had a great can of boiling water ready in one of the rooms upstairs , and when they heard her steps coming round that side of the house , they threw open the window and emptied it all over her head ; and that was the end of her .

text: once upon a time there lived a queen who was deeply in love with a prince , but he could not marry anyone , because he was under an enchantment . so the queen set out to seek a fairy , and asked what she could do to win the prince 's love . the fairy said to her : " you know that the prince has a great cat which he is very fond of . whoever is clever enough to tread on that cat 's tail is the woman he is destined to marry . " at last , however , she was lucky enough to come upon puss fast asleep and with her tail conveniently spread out . so the queen , without losing a moment , set her foot upon it heavily . with one terrific yell the cat sprang up and instantly changed into a tall woman , who , fixing her angry eyes upon the queen , said : " you shall marry the prince because you have been able to break the enchantment , but i will have my revenge . you shall have a daughter , who will never be happy until she finds out that her nose is too long , and if you ever tell anyone what i have just said to you , you shall vanish away instantly , and no one shall ever see you or hear of you again . " though the queen was horribly afraid of the enchantress , she could not help laughing at this threat . " if my daughter has such a long nose as that , " she said to herself , " she must always see it or feel it ; at least , if she is not blind or without hands . "

text: once upon a time there lived a queen who was deeply in love with a prince , but he could not marry anyone , because he was under an enchantment . so the queen set out to seek a fairy , and asked what she could do to win the prince 's love . the fairy said to her : " you know that the prince has a great cat which he is very fond of . whoever is clever enough to tread on that cat 's tail is the woman he is destined to marry . " the queen said to herself that this would not be very difficult , and she left the fairy , determined to grind the cat 's tail to powder rather than not tread on it at all . you may imagine that it was not long before she went to see the prince , and puss , as usual , marched in before her , arching her back . the queen took a long step , and quite thought she had the tail under her foot , but the cat turned round so sharply that she only trod on air . and so it went on for eight days , till the queen began to think that this fatal tail must be full of quicksilver - it was never still for a moment . at last , however , she was lucky enough to come upon puss fast asleep and with her tail conveniently spread out . so the queen , without losing a moment , set her foot upon it heavily . with one terrific yell the cat sprang up and instantly changed into a tall woman , who , fixing her angry eyes upon the queen , said : " you shall marry the prince because you have been able to break the enchantment , but i will have my revenge . you shall have a daughter , who will never be happy until she finds out that her nose is too long , and if you ever tell anyone what i have just said to you , you shall vanish away instantly , and no one shall ever see you or hear of you again . " though the queen was horribly afraid of the enchantress , she could not help laughing at this threat . " if my daughter has such a long nose as that , " she said to herself , " she must always see it or feel it ; at least , if she is not blind or without hands . "

question: who did the princess see when she caught sight of a light , which seemed to shine from a cavern ?

text: the princess was left quite unconsolable , and declared that nothing should induce her to go back to her kingdom until she had found him again , and refusing to allow any of her courtiers to follow her , she mounted her horse and rode sadly away , letting the animal choose her own path . so it happened that she came presently to a great plain , across which she rode all day long without seeing a single house , and horse and rider were terribly hungry , when , as the night fell , the princess caught sight of a light , which seemed to shine from a cavern . she rode up to it , and saw a little old man , who appeared to be at least a hundred years old . he put on his spectacles to look at princess hyacinth , but it was quite a long time before he could fix them securely because his nose was so very short .

question: why did the old fairy wish to make the princess happy and hit upon a plan ?
answer1: she was the daughter of the old fairy 's best friend .

text: the princess and the fairy ( for that was who he was ) had no sooner looked at one another than they went into fits of laughter , and cried at the same moment , " oh , what a funny nose ! " " not so funny as your own , " said princess hyacinth to the fairy ; " but , madam , i beg you to leave the consideration of our noses - such as they are - and to be good enough to give me something to eat , for i am starving , and so is my poor horse . " " with all my heart , " said the fairy . " though your nose is so ridiculous you are , nevertheless , the daughter of my best friend . i loved your mother as if she had been my sister . now she had a very handsome nose ! " " and pray what does mine lack ? " said the princess . " oh ! it does not lack anything , " replied the fairy . " on the contrary quite , there is only too much of it . but never mind , one may be a very worthy woman though her nose is too long . i was telling you that i was your mother 's friend ; she often came to see me in the old times , and you must know that i was very pretty in those days ; at least , she used to say so . i should like to tell you of a conversation we had the last time i ever saw her . " " indeed , " said the princess , " when i have supped it will give me the greatest pleasure to hear it ; but consider , madam , i beg of you , that i have had nothing to eat to - day . " in an instant the crystal prison flew into a thousand splinters , and the old fairy , taking the dear little prince by the hand , said to the princess : " now , say if you are not very much obliged to me . much good it was for me to talk to you about your nose ! you would never have found out how extraordinary it was if it had not hindered you from doing what you wanted to . you see how self - love keeps us from knowing our own defects of mind and body . our reason tries in vain to show them to us ; we refuse to see them till we find them in the way of our interests . " princess hyacinth , whose nose was now just like anyone 's else , did not fail to profit by the lesson she had received . she married the dear little prince , and they lived happily ever after .
answer2: the old fairy and the princess 's mother were friends .
answer3: the old fairy knew her mother .

question: where did the old fairy shut the dear little prince up ?
answer1: a palace of crystal
answer4: in a palace of crystal
text: the old fairy , who wished to make her happy , at last hit upon a plan . he shut the dear little prince up in a palace of crystal , and put this palace down where the princess would not fail to find it . her joy at seeing the prince again was extreme , and she set to work with all her might to try to break his prison ; but in spite of all her efforts she failed utterly . in despair she thought at least that she would try to get near enough to speak to the dear little prince , who , on his part , stretched out his hand that she might kiss it ; but turn which way she might , she never could raise it to her lips , for her long nose always prevented it . for the first time she realized how long it really was , and exclaimed : " well , it must be admitted that my nose is too long ! "

question: why did the king command that the portraits of several princes should be brought for the princess to see ?
answer1: the king thought it was time that she should be married .
answer4: he thought she should be married
text: when she grew sensible she learned history ; and whenever any great princess or beautiful prince was spoken of , her teachers took care to tell her that they had long noses . her room was hung with pictures , all of people with very large noses ; and the princess grew up so convinced that a long nose was a great beauty , that she would not on any account have had her own a single inch shorter ! when her twentieth birthday was passed the king thought it was time that she should be married , so he commanded that the portraits of several princes should be brought for her to see , and among the others was a picture of the dear little prince !

question: who was the son of a great queen and would some day possess several kingdoms himself ?
answer1: the dear little prince
answer4: dear little prince
text: now , he was the son of a great queen , and would some day possess several kingdoms himself ; but princess hyacinth had not a thought to spare for anything of that sort , she was so much struck with his beauty . the prince , whom she thought quite charming , had , however , a little saucy nose , which , in his face , was the prettiest thing possible , but it was a cause of great embarrassment to the courtiers , who had got into such a habit of laughing at little noses that they sometimes found themselves laughing at hers before they had time to think ; but this did not do at all before the princess , who quite failed to see the joke , and actually banished two of her courtiers who had dared to mention disrespectfully the dear little prince 's tiny nose !

question: how did the princess feel about her nose ?
answer1: she was quite satisfied with it .
answer4: quite satisfied
text: " my dear princess , might i beg you to move a little more that way , for your nose casts such a shadow that i really can not see what i have on my plate . ah ! thanks . now let us speak of your mother . when i went to her court she was only a little girl , but that is forty years ago , and i have been in this desolate place ever since . tell me what goes on nowadays ; are the gentlemen as fond of amusement as ever ? in my time one saw them at parties , theatres , balls , and promenades every day . dear me ! what a long nose you have ! i can not get used to it ! " " really , madam , " said the princess , " i wish you would leave off mentioning my nose . it can not matter to you what it is like . i am quite satisfied with it , and have no wish to have it shorter . one must take what is given one . " " now you are angry with me , my poor hyacinth , " said the fairy , " and i assure you that i did not mean to vex you ; on the contrary , i wished to do you a service . however , though i really can not help your nose being a shock to me , i will try not to say anything about it . i will even try to think that you have an ordinary nose . to tell the truth , it would make three reasonable ones . "

question: why did the enchantress want to have her revenge on the queen ?
answer1: the queen set her foot upon its tail heavily .
answer4: the enchantment was broken
text: at last , however , she was lucky enough to come upon puss fast asleep and with her tail conveniently spread out . so the queen , without losing a moment , set her foot upon it heavily . with one terrific yell the cat sprang up and instantly changed into a tall woman , who , fixing her angry eyes upon the queen , said : " you shall marry the prince because you have been able to break the enchantment , but i will have my revenge . you shall have a daughter , who will never be happy until she finds out that her nose is too long , and if you ever tell anyone what i have just said to you , you shall vanish away instantly , and no one shall ever see you or hear of you again . " though the queen was horribly afraid of the enchantress , she could not help laughing at this threat . " if my daughter has such a long nose as that , " she said to herself , " she must always see it or feel it ; at least , if she is not blind or without hands . "

question: what did the gentlemen do when the princess was old enough to speak ?
answer1: told the princess all sorts of dreadful stories about people who had short noses
answer4: told her all sorts of dreadful stories about people who had short noses
text: the princess was brought up with great care ; and , as soon as she could speak , they told her all sorts of dreadful stories about people who had short noses . no one was allowed to come near her whose nose did not more or less resemble her own , and the courtiers , to get into favor with the king , took to pulling their babies ' noses several times every day to make them grow long . but , do what they would , they were nothing by comparison with the princess 's .

question: why did n't the king know the reason for his daughter 's enormous nose ?
answer1: the queen could not ever tell anyone what that enchantress had just said to her .

text: at last , however , she was lucky enough to come upon puss fast asleep and with her tail conveniently spread out . so the queen , without losing a moment , set her foot upon it heavily . with one terrific yell the cat sprang up and instantly changed into a tall woman , who , fixing her angry eyes upon the queen , said : " you shall marry the prince because you have been able to break the enchantment , but i will have my revenge . you shall have a daughter , who will never be happy until she finds out that her nose is too long , and if you ever tell anyone what i have just said to you , you shall vanish away instantly , and no one shall ever see you or hear of you again . " though the queen was horribly afraid of the enchantress , she could not help laughing at this threat . " if my daughter has such a long nose as that , " she said to herself , " she must always see it or feel it ; at least , if she is not blind or without hands . " but , as the enchantress had vanished , she did not waste any more time in thinking , but went to seek the prince , who very soon consented to marry her . but after all , they had not been married very long when the queen died , and the king had nothing left to care for but his little daughter , who was called hyacinth . the little princess had large blue eyes , the prettiest eyes in the world , and a sweet little mouth , but , alas ! her nose was so enormous that it covered half her face . the king was inconsolable when he saw this great nose , but his gentlemen assured him that it was not really as large as it looked ; that it was a roman nose , and you had only to open any history to see that every heroine has a large nose . the king , who was devoted to his baby , was pleased with what they told him , and when he looked at hyacinth again , her nose certainly did not seem to him quite so large .

question: who were fighting when the daughter of the queen of tethertown reached the great battle ?
answer1: a snake and a great black raven
answer4: a snake and a great black rave
text: there was to be a great battle between all the creatures of the earth and the birds of the air . news of it went abroad , and the daughter of the queen of tethertown said that when the battle was fought she would be there to see it , and would bring back word who was to be queen . but in spite of that , she was almost too late , and every fight had been fought save the last , which was between a snake and a great black raven . both struck hard , but in the end the snake proved the stronger , and would have twisted herself round the neck of the raven till she died had not the queen 's daughter drawn her sword , and cut off the head of the snake at a single blow . and when the raven beheld that her enemy was dead , she was grateful , and said : ' for thy kindness to me this day , i will show thee a sight . so come up now on the root of my two wings . ' the queen 's daughter did as she was bid , and before the raven stopped flying , they had passed over seven bens and seven glens and seven mountain moors . ' do you see that house yonder ? ' said the raven at last . ' go straight for it , for a brother of mine dwells there , and he will make you right welcome . and if he asks , " wert thou at the battle of the birds ? " answer that thou wert , and if he asks , " didst thou see my likeness ? " answer that thou sawest it , but be sure thou meetest me in the morning at this place . '

question: what did the queen 's daughter do after she went into the brother 's house ?
answer1: had meat of each meat , and drink of each drink , warm water for her feet , and a soft bed to lie in
answer4: she had meat of each meat , and drink of each drink , warm water for her feet , and a soft bed to lie in
text: the queen 's daughter followed what the raven told her and that night she had meat of each meat , and drink of each drink , warm water for her feet , and a soft bed to lie in . thus it happened the next day , and the next , but on the fourth meeting , instead of meeting the raven , in her place the queen 's daughter found waiting for her the handsomest youth that ever was seen , with a bundle in her hand . ' is there a raven hereabouts ? ' asked the queen 's daughter , and the youth answered : ' i am that raven , and i was delivered by thee from the spells that bound me , and in reward thou wilt get this bundle . go back by the road thou camest , and lie as before , a night in each house , but be careful not to unloose the bundle till thou art in the place wherein thou wouldst most wish to dwell . ' then the queen 's daughter set out , and thus it happened as it had happened before , till she entered a thick wood near her mother 's house . she had walked a long way and suddenly the bundle seemed to grow heavier ; first she put it down under a tree , and next she thought she would look at it .

question: what did the queen 's daughter see after she unfastened the bundle ?
answer1: a great castle with an orchard
answer4: a great castle with an orchard all about it
text: the string was easy to untie , and the queen 's daughter soon unfastened the bundle . what was it she saw there ? why , a great castle with an orchard all about it , and in the orchard fruit and flowers and birds of very kind . it was all ready for her to dwell in , but instead of being in the midst of the forest , she did wish she had left the bundle unloosed till she had reached the green valley close to her mother 's palace . well , it was no use wishing , and with a sigh she glanced up , and beheld a huge giant coming towards her . ' bad is the place where thou hast built thy house , queen 's daughter , ' said the giant . ' true ; it is not here that i wish to be , ' answered the queen 's daughter . ' what reward wilt thou give me if i put it back in the bundle ? ' asked the giant . ' what reward dost thou ask ? ' answered the queen 's daughter . ' the first girl thou hast when she is seven years old , ' said the giant . ' if i have a girl thou shalt get her , ' answered the queen 's daughter , and as she spoke the castle and the orchard were tied up in the bundle again . ' now take thy road , and i will take mine , ' said the giant . ' and if thou forgettest thy promise , i will remember it . '

question: who did the king give to the giant ?
answer1: the cook 's daughter
answer4: the cook 's daughter
text: the queen glanced at her husband , who nodded , so she answered : ' let her father first put her in order , ' and the king left the hall , and took the cook 's daughter and dressed her in the princess 's clothes , and led her up to the giant , who held her hand , and together they went out along the road . they had not walked far when the giant stopped and stretched out a stick to the girl . ' if your mother had that stick , what would she do with it ? ' asked she . ' if my mother had that stick , she would beat the dogs and cats that steal the queen 's meat , ' replied the girl . ' thou art the cook 's daughter ! ' cried the giant . ' go home to thy father ' ; and turning her back she strode straight to the castle . ' if you seek to trick me this time , the highest stone will soon be the lowest , ' said she , and the queen and king trembled , but they could not bear to give up their girl . ' the butler 's daughter is the same age as ours , ' whispered the king ; ' she will not know the difference , ' and he took the child and dressed her in the princess 's clothes , and the giant let her away along the road . before they had gone far she stopped , and held out a stick . ' if thy mother had that rod , what would she do with it ? ' asked the giant . ' she would beat the dogs and cats that break the queen 's glasses , ' answered the girl .

text: ' thou art the daughter of the butler ! ' cried the giant . ' go home to thy father ' ; and turning round she strode back angrily to the castle . ' bring out thy daughter at once , ' roared she , ' or the stone that is highest will be lowest , ' and this time the real princess was brought . but though her parents wept bitterly and fancied the child was suffering all kinds of dreadful things , the giant treated her like her own daughter , though she never allowed her to see her sons . the girl grew to be a big girl , and one day the giant told her that she would have to amuse herself alone for many hours , as she had a journey to make . so the girl wandered to the top of the castle , where she had never been before . there she paused , for the sound of music broke upon her ears , and opening a door near her , she beheld a boy sitting by the window , holding a harp . ' haste and begone , i see the giant close at hand , ' he whispered hurriedly , ' but when she is asleep , return hither , for i would speak with thee . ' and the princess did as she was bid , and when midnight struck she crept back to the top of the castle . ' to - morrow , ' said the boy , who was the giant 's son , ' to - morrow thou wilt get the choice of my two brothers to marry , but thou must answer that thou wilt not take either , but only me . this will anger her greatly , for she wishes to betroth me to the daughter of the queen of the green city , whom i like not at all . '

question: who did the girl need to choose as her husband ?
answer1: one of her two elder sons
answer4: himself
text: then they parted , and on the morrow , as the boy had said , the giant called her three sons to her , and likewise the young princess to whom she spoke . ' now , o daughter of the queen of tethertown , the time has come for us to part . choose one of my two elder sons to husband , and thou shalt take him to your mother 's house the day after the wedding . ' ' give me the youngest instead , ' replied the youth , and the giant 's face darkened as she heard her . ' three things must thou do first , ' said she . ' say on , i will do them , ' replied the princess , and the giant left the house , and bade her follow to the byre , where the cows were kept . ' for a hundred years no woman has swept this byre , ' said the giant , ' but if by nightfall , when i reach home , thou has not cleaned it so that a golden apple can roll through it from end to end , thy blood shall pay for it . ' all day long the youth toiled , but she might as well have tried to empty the ocean . at length , when she was so tire d she could hardly move , the giant 's youngest son stood in the doorway .

question: what happened after the girl fell asleep ?
answer1: the boy had disappeared , and the byre was so clean that a golden apple could roll from end to end of it .

text: ' lay down thy weariness , ' said he , and the queen 's daughter , thinking she could only die once , sank on the floor at his bidding , and fell sound asleep . when she woke the boy had disappeared , and the byre was so clean that a golden apple could roll from end to end of it . she jumped up in surprise , and at that moment in came the giant . ' hast thou cleaned the byre , queen 's daughter ? ' asked she . ' i have cleaned it , ' answered she . ' well , since thou wert so active to - day , to - morrow thou wilt thatch this byre with a feather from every different bird , or else thy blood shall pay for it , ' and she went out . before the sun was up , the youth took her bow and her quiver and set off to kill the birds . off to the moor she went , but never a bird was to be seen that day . at last she got so tired with running to and fro that she gave up heart . ' there is but one death i can die , ' thought she . then at midday came the giant 's son . ' thou art tired , queen 's daughter ? ' asked he . ' i am , ' answered she ; ' all these hours have i wandered , and there fell but these two blackbirds , both of one colour . ' ' lay down thy weariness on the grass , ' said he , and she did as he bade her , and fell fast asleep .

' hast thou cleaned the byre , queen 's daughter ? ' asked she . ' i have cleaned it , ' answered she . ' well , since thou wert so active to - day , to - morrow thou wilt thatch this byre with a feather from every different bird , or else thy blood shall pay for it , ' and she went out . before the sun was up , the youth took her bow and her quiver and set off to kill the birds . off to the moor she went , but never a bird was to be seen that day . at last she got so tired with running to and fro that she gave up heart . ' there is but one death i can die , ' thought she . then at midday came the giant 's son . ' thou art tired , queen 's daughter ? ' asked he . ' i am , ' answered she ; ' all these hours have i wandered , and there fell but these two blackbirds , both of one colour . ' ' lay down thy weariness on the grass , ' said he , and she did as he bade her , and fell fast asleep .

question: what happened after the girl returned to the byre ?
answer1: the byre was thatched .
answer4: it was beautifully thatched
text: when she woke the boy had disappeared , and she got up , and returned to the byre . as she drew near , she rubbed her eyes hard , thinking she was dreaming , for there it was , beautifully thatched , just as the giant had wished . at the door of the house she met the giant . ' hast thou thatched the byre , queen 's daughter ? ' ' i have thatched it . ' ' well , since thou hast been so active to - day , i have something else for thee ! beside the loch thou seest over yonder there grows a fir tree . on the top of the fir tree is a magpie 's nest , and in the nest are five eggs . thou wilt bring me those eggs for breakfast , and if one is cracked or broken , thy blood shall pay for it . ' before it was light next day , the queen 's daughter jumped out of bed and ran down to the loch . the tree was not hard to find , for the rising sun shone red on the trunk , which was five hundred feet from the ground to its first branch . time after time she walked round it , trying to find some knots , however small , where she could put her feet , but the bark was quite smooth , and she soon saw that if she was to reach the top at all , it must be by climbing up with her knees like a sailor . but then she was a queen 's daughter and not a sailor , which made all the difference .
answer2: the byre was beautifully thatched with feathers .

question: what happened after the girl tried to get the eggs ?
answer1: she could not climb the tree .
answer4: try she did till her hands and knees were sore
text: however , it was no use standing there staring at the fir , at least she must try to do her best , and try she did till her hands and knees were sore , for as soon as she had struggled up a few feet , she slid back again . once she climbed a little higher than before , and hope rose in her heart , then down she came with such force that her hands and knees smarted worse than ever . ' this is no time for stopping , ' said the voice of the giant 's son , as she leant against the trunk to recover her breath . ' alas ! i am no sooner up than down , ' answered she . ' try once more , ' said he , and he laid a finger against the tree and bade her put her foot on it . then he placed another finger a little higher up , and so on till she reached the top , where the magpie had built his nest . ' make haste now with the nest , ' he cried , ' for my mother 's breath is burning my back , ' and down she scrambled as fast as she could , but the boy 's little finger had caught in a branch at the top , and he was obliged to leave it there . but he was too busy to pay heed to this , for the sun was getting high over the hills . ' listen to me , ' he said . ' this night my two brothers and i will be dressed in the same garments , and you will not know me . but when my mother says ' go to thy husband , queen 's daughter , ' come to the one whose right hand has no little finger . '
answer2: she could not reach the nest .
answer5: she had struggled up a few feet , she slid back again

question: what happened after the girl did these three things for the giant ?
answer1: the giant allowed her to marry the youngest son .

text: so she went and gave the eggs to the giant , who nodded her head . ' make ready for thy marriage , ' cried she , ' for the wedding shall take place this very night , and i will summon thy bridegroom to greet thee . ' then her three sons were sent for , and they all entered dressed in green silk of the same fashion , and with golden circlets round their heads . the queen 's daughter looked from one to another . which was the youngest ? suddenly her eyes fell on the hand of the middle one , and there was no little finger . ' thou hast aimed well this time too , ' said the giant , as the queen 's daughter laid her hand on his shoulder , ' but perhaps we may meet some other way ' ; and though she pretended to laugh , the bridegroom saw a gleam in her eye which warned him of danger . the wedding took place that very night , and the hall was filled with giants and ladies , and they danced till the house shook from top to bottom . at last everyone grew tired , and the guests went away , and the queen 's daughter and her bridegroom were left alone .

question: what would happen if the queen 's daughter stayed until dawn ?
answer1: his mother would kill her .
answer4: the giant would kill her
text: ' if we stay here till dawn my mother will kill thee , ' he whispered , ' but thou art my wife and i will save thee , as i did before , ' and he cut an apple into nine pieces , and put two pieces at the head of the bed , and two pieces at the foot , and two pieces at the door of the kitchen , and two at the big door , and one outside the house . and when this was done , and he heard the giant snoring , he and the queen 's daughter crept out softly and stole across to the stable , where he led out the blue - grey mare and jumped on its back , and his wife mounted behind him . not long after , the giant awoke . ' are you asleep ? ' asked she . ' not yet , ' answered the apple at the head of the bed , and the giant turned over , and soon was snoring as loudly as before . by and bye she called again . ' are you asleep ? ' ' not yet , ' said the apple at the foot of the bed , and the giant was satisfied . after a while , she called a third time , ' are you asleep ? ' ' not yet , ' replied the apple in the kitchen , but when in a few minutes , she put the question for the fourth time and received an answer from the apple outside the house door , she guessed what had happened , and ran to the room to look for herself . the bed was cold and empty !
answer5: she would be killed by the giant

text: ' if we stay here till dawn my mother will kill thee , ' he whispered , ' but thou art my wife and i will save thee , as i did before , ' and he cut an apple into nine pieces , and put two pieces at the head of the bed , and two pieces at the foot , and two pieces at the door of the kitchen , and two at the big door , and one outside the house . and when this was done , and he heard the giant snoring , he and the queen 's daughter crept out softly and stole across to the stable , where he led out the blue - grey mare and jumped on its back , and his wife mounted behind him . not long after , the giant awoke . ' are you asleep ? ' asked she . ' not yet , ' answered the apple at the head of the bed , and the giant turned over , and soon was snoring as loudly as before . by and bye she called again . ' are you asleep ? ' ' not yet , ' said the apple at the foot of the bed , and the giant was satisfied . after a while , she called a third time , ' are you asleep ? ' ' not yet , ' replied the apple in the kitchen , but when in a few minutes , she put the question for the fourth time and received an answer from the apple outside the house door , she guessed what had happened , and ran to the room to look for herself . the bed was cold and empty !
answer2: he needed the giant to stay asleep .
answer5: the apples tricked the giant into thinking the daughter was awake

question: what did the bridegroom tell the queen 's daughter to do after he knew the giant was chasing them ?
answer1: put her hand into the ear of the mare and whatever she found there , throw it behind her
answer4: put her hand in the ear of the mare and throw whatever she finds in there
text: ' my mother 's breath is burning my back , ' cried the boy , ' put thy hand into the ear of the mare , and whatever thou findest there , throw it behind thee . ' and in the mare 's ear there was a twig of sloe tree , and as she threw it behind her there sprung up twenty miles of thornwood so thick that scarce a weasel could go through it . and the giant , who was striding headlong forwards , got caught in it , and it pulled her hair and beard . ' this is one of my son 's tricks , ' she said to herself , ' but if i had my big axe and my wood - knife , i would not be long making a way through this , ' and off she went home and brought back the axe and the wood - knife . it took her but a short time to cut a road through the blackthorn , and then she laid the axe and the knife under a tree . ' i will leave them there till i return , ' she murmured to herself , but a hoodie crow , which was sitting on a branch above , heard her . ' if thou leavest them , ' said the hoodie , ' we will steal them . ' ' you will , ' answered the giant , ' and i must take them home . ' so she took them home , and started afresh on her journey . ' my mother 's breath is burning my back , ' cried the boy at midday . ' put thy finger in the mare 's ear and throw behind thee whatever thou findest in it , ' and the queen 's daughter found a splinter of grey stone , and threw it behind her , and in a twinkling twenty miles of solid rock lay between them and the giant .

text: ' my son 's tricks are the hardest things that ever met me , ' said the giant , ' but if i had my lever and my crowbar , i would not be long in making my way through this rock also , ' but as she had got them , she had to go home and fetch them . then it took her but a short time to hew her way through the rock . text: the blue - grey mare galloped on like the wind , and the next day the queen 's daughter came in sight of her mother 's house . ' get down and go in , ' said the bridegroom , ' and tell them that thou hast married me . but take heed that neither woman nor beast kiss thee , for then thou wilt cease to remember me at all . ' ' i will do thy bidding , ' answered she , and left him at the gate . all who met her bade her welcome , and she charged her mother and father not to kiss her , but as she greeted them her old greyhound leapt on her neck , and kissed her on the mouth . and after that she did not remember the giant 's son .

question: who dwelled near the well ?
answer1: the husband of a shoemaker
answer4: the husband of a shoemaker
text: all that day he sat on a well which was near the gate , waiting , waiting , but the queen 's daughter never came . in the darkness he climbed up into an oak tree that shadowed the well , and there he lay all night , waiting , waiting . on the morrow , at midday , the husband of a shoemaker who dwelt near the well went to draw water for his wife to drink , and he saw the shadow of the boy in the tree , and thought it was his own shadow . ' how handsome i am , to be sure , ' said he , gazing into the well , and as he stopped to behold himself better , the jug struck against the stones and broke in pieces , and he was forced to return to his wife without the water , and this angered her . ' thou hast turned crazy , ' said she in wrath . ' go thou , my son , and fetch me a drink , ' and the boy went , and the same thing befell him as had befallen his father . ' where is the water ? ' asked the shoemaker , when he came back , and as he held nothing save the handle of the jug she went to the well herself . she too saw the reflection of the man in the tree , but looked up to discover whence it came , and there above her sat the most beautiful man in the world . ' come down , ' she said , ' for a while thou ca nst stay in my house , ' and glad enough the boy was to come .

question: why did the young women need to buy the finest shoes ?
answer1: to wear at the wedding
answer4: the queen of the country was about to marry
text: now the queen of the country was about to marry , and the young women about the court thronged the shoemaker 's shop to buy fine shoes to wear at the wedding . ' thou hast a pretty son , ' said they when they beheld the boy sitting at work . ' pretty he is , ' answered the shoemaker , ' but no son of mine . ' ' i would give a hundred pounds to marry him , ' said one . ' and i , ' ' and i , ' cried the others . ' that is no business of mine , ' answered the shoemaker , and the young women bade her ask him if he would choose one of them for a wife , and to tell them on the morrow . then the shoemaker asked him , and the boy said that he would marry the one who would bring her purse with her . so the shoemaker hurried to the youth who had first spoken , and she came back , and after giving the shoemaker a hundred pounds for her news , she sought the boy , who was waiting for her . ' is it thou ? ' inquired he . ' i am thirsty , give me a drink from the well that is yonder . ' and she poured out the water , but she could not move from the place where she was ; and there she stayed till many hours had passed by . ' take away that foolish girl , ' cried the boy to the shoemaker at last , ' i am tired of her , ' and then suddenly she was able to walk , and betook herself to her home , but she did not tell the others what had happened to her .

question: what did the youngest son tell one of the other young women to do ?
answer1: see if the latch is on the door .
answer4: see if the latch is on the door
text: next day there arrived one of the other young women , and in the evening , when the shoemaker had gone out and they were alone , he said to her , ' see if the latch is on the door . ' the young woman hastened to do his bidding , but as soon as she touched the latch , her fingers stuck to it , and there she had to stay for many hours , till the shoemaker came back , and the boy let her go . hanging her head , she went home , but she told no one what had befallen her . then was the turn of the third woman , and her foot remained fastened to the floor , till the boy unloosed it . and thankfully , she ran off , and was not seen looking behind her . ' take the purse of gold , ' said the boy to the shoemaker , ' i have no need of it , and it will better thee . ' and the shoemaker took it and told the boy she must carry the shoes for the wedding up to the castle . ' i would fain get a sight of the queen 's daughter before she marries , ' sighed he . ' come with me , then , ' answered she ; ' the servants are all my friends , and they will let you stand in the passage down which the queen 's daughter will pass , and all the company too . '

' the young woman hastened to do his bidding , but as soon as she touched the latch , her fingers stuck to it , and there she had to stay for many hours , till the shoemaker came back , and the boy let her go . hanging her head , she went home , but she told no one what had befallen her . then was the turn of the third woman , and her foot remained fastened to the floor , till the boy unloosed it . and thankfully , she ran off , and was not seen looking behind her . text: up they went to the castle , and when the young women saw the boy standing there , they led him into the hall where the banquet was laid out and poured him out some wine . he was just raising the glass to drink when a flame went up out of it , and out of the flame sprang two pigeons , one of gold and one of silver . they flew round and round the head of the boy , when three grains of barley fell on the floor , and the silver pigeon dived down , and swallowed them . ' if thou hadst remembered how i cleaned the byre , thou wouldst have given me my share , ' cooed the golden pigeon , and as she spoke three more grains fell , and the silver pigeon ate them as before . ' if thou hadst remembered how i thatched the byre , thou wouldst have given me my share , ' cooed the golden pigeon again ; and as she spoke three more grains fell , and for the third time they were eaten by the silver pigeon . ' if thou hadst remembered how i got the magpie 's nest , thou wouldst have given me my share , ' cooed the golden pigeon . then the queen 's daughter understood that they had come to remind her of what she had forgotten , and her lost memory came back , and she knew her husband , and kissed him . but as the preparations had been made , it seemed a pity to waste them , so they were married a second time , and sat down to the wedding feast .

question: what was the wicked manito in the disguise of ?
answer1: an old indian
answer4: an old indian
text: in a region of country where the forest and the prairie strived which should be the most beautiful - the open plain , with its free sunshine and winds and flowers , or the close wood , with its delicious twilight - walks and enamored haunts - there lived a wicked manito in the disguise of an old indian . although the country furnished an abundance of game , and whatever else a good heart could wish for , it was the study of this wicked genius to destroy such as fell into her hands . she made use of all her arts to decoy women into her power , for the purpose of killing them . the country had been once thickly peopled , but this mudjee monedo had so thinned it by her cruel practices , that she now lived almost solitary in the wilderness . the secret of her success lay in her great speed . she had the power to assume the shape of any four - footed creature , and it was her custom to challenge such as she sought to destroy , to run with her . she had a beaten path on which she ran , leading around a large lake , and she always ran around this circle so that the starting and the winning - post was the same .

question: why did the mudjee monedo almost live in solitude in the wilderness ?
answer1: had so thinned the people by her cruel practices
answer4: she had so thinned the people by her cruel practices

text: in a region of country where the forest and the prairie strived which should be the most beautiful - the open plain , with its free sunshine and winds and flowers , or the close wood , with its delicious twilight - walks and enamored haunts - there lived a wicked manito in the disguise of an old indian . although the country furnished an abundance of game , and whatever else a good heart could wish for , it was the study of this wicked genius to destroy such as fell into her hands . she made use of all her arts to decoy women into her power , for the purpose of killing them . the country had been once thickly peopled , but this mudjee monedo had so thinned it by her cruel practices , that she now lived almost solitary in the wilderness . the secret of her success lay in her great speed . she had the power to assume the shape of any four - footed creature , and it was her custom to challenge such as she sought to destroy , to run with her . she had a beaten path on which she ran , leading around a large lake , and she always ran around this circle so that the starting and the winning - post was the same .

question: how did the mudjee monedo leave her competitor behind ?
answer1: changed herself into a fox , wolf , deer , or other swift - footed animal
answer4: she changed herself into a fox , wolf , deer , or other swift - footed animal , and was thus able to leave her competitor behind
text: whoever failed as every one had , yielded up her life at this post ; and although she ran every day , no woman was ever known to beat this evil genius ; for whenever she was pressed hard , she changed herself into a fox , wolf , deer , or other swift - footed animal , and was thus able to leave her competitor behind . the whole country was in dread of this same mudjee monedo , and yet the young women were constantly running with her ; for if they refused , she called them cowards , which was a reproach they could not bear . they would rather die than be called cowards . to keep up her sport , the manito made light of these deadly foot - matches , and instead of assuming a braggart air , and going about in a boastful way , with the blood of such as she had overcome , upon her hands , she adopted very pleasing manners , and visited the lodges around the country as any other sweet - tempered and harmless old indian might .

question: why did the young women rather die ?
answer1: they would rather die than be called cowards .
answer4: they would rather die than be called cowards
text: whoever failed as every one had , yielded up her life at this post ; and although she ran every day , no woman was ever known to beat this evil genius ; for whenever she was pressed hard , she changed herself into a fox , wolf , deer , or other swift - footed animal , and was thus able to leave her competitor behind . the whole country was in dread of this same mudjee monedo , and yet the young women were constantly running with her ; for if they refused , she called them cowards , which was a reproach they could not bear . they would rather die than be called cowards . to keep up her sport , the manito made light of these deadly foot - matches , and instead of assuming a braggart air , and going about in a boastful way , with the blood of such as she had overcome , upon her hands , she adopted very pleasing manners , and visited the lodges around the country as any other sweet - tempered and harmless old indian might .

question: what did the mudjee monedo do to learn whether the young girls were old enough to run with her ?
answer1: kept a very sharp eye upon their growth , and the day she thought them ready , she did not fail to challenge them to a trial on her racing - ground
answer4: she kept a very sharp eye upon their growth
text: her secret object in these friendly visits was to learn whether the young girls were getting old enough to run with her ; she kept a very sharp eye upon their growth , and the day she thought them ready , she did not fail to challenge them to a trial on her racing - ground . there was not a family in all that beautiful region which had not in this way been visited and thinned out ; and the manito had quite naturally come to be held in abhorrence by all the indian fathers in the country . it happened that there lived near her a poor widower man , whose wife and seven daughters she had made way with ; and he was now living with an only son , and a daughter of ten or twelve years old . this widower was very poor and feeble , and he suffered so much for lack of food and other comforts of the lodge , that he would have been glad to die , but for his son and his little daughter . the mudjee monedo had already visited his lodge to observe whether the girl was sufficiently grown to be challenged to the race ; and so crafty in her approaches and so soft in her manners was the monedo , that the father feared that she would yet decoy the daughter and make way with her as she had done with her mother and her seven sisters , in spite of all his struggles to save her .

question: who was the widower man 's son ?
answer1: minda
answer4: minda
text: and yet he strove with all his might to strengthen his daughter in every good course . he taught her , as best he could , what was becoming for the wise hunter and the brave warrior . he remembered and set before her all that he could recall of the skill and the craft of her mother and her sisters who were lost . the widower man also instructed his son in whatever could make him useful as a husband ; and in the leisure - time of the lodge , he gave his lessons in the art of working with the quills of porcupine , and bestowed on his such other accomplishments as should make him an ornament and a blessing to his wife 's household . the son , minda by name , was kind and obedient to his father , and never failed in his duty . their lodge stood high up on the banks of a lake , which gave them a wide prospect of country , embellished with groves and open fields , which waved with the blue light of their long grass , and made , at all hours of sun and moon , a cheerful scene to look upon . across this beautiful prairie , minda had one morning made his way to gather dry limbs for their fire ; for he disdained no labor of the lodge . and while enjoying the sweetness of the air and the green beauty of the woods , he strolled far away .

question: where did minda come across a bird of red and deep - blue plumage softly blended ?
answer1: a bank
answer4: a bank
text: he had come to a bank , painted with flowers of every hue , and was reclining on its fragrant couch , when a bird , of red and deep - blue plumage softly blended , alighted on a branch near by , and began to pour forth its carol . it was a bird of strange character , such as he had never before seen . it s first note was so delicious to the ear of minda , and it so pierced to his young heart , that he listened as he had never before to any mortal or heavenly sound . it seemed like the human voice , forbidden to speak , and uttering its language through this wild wood - chant with a mournful melody , as if it bewailed the lack of the power or the right to make itself more plainly intelligible . the voice of the bird rose and fell , and circled round and round , but whithersoever floated or spread out its notes , they seemed ever to have their center where minda sat ; and he looked with sad eyes into the sad eyes of the mournful bird , that sat in her red and deep - blue plumage just opposite to the flowery bank . the poor bird strove more and more with her voice , and seemed ever more and more anxiously to address her notes of lament to minda 's ear , till at last he could not refrain from saying , " what aileth thee , sad bird ? "

question: who was the bird lover ?
answer1: monedowa
answer4: monedowa
text: at last the widower began himself to have a suspicion that his son 's heart was in the wood , from his long delays in returning , and the little success he had in gathering the fire - branches for which he went in search . in answer to his father 's questions , minda revealed the truth , and made known his lover 's request . the father , considering the lonely and destitute condition of his little household , gave his consent . the son , with light steps , hastened with the news to the wood . the bird lover of course heard it with delight , and fluttered through the air in happy circles , and poured forth a song of joy which thrilled minda to the heart . she said that she would come to the lodge at sunset , and immediately took wing , while minda hung fondly upon her flight , till she was lost far away in the blue sky . with the twilight the bird lover , whose name was monedowa , appeared at the door of the lodge , as a hunter , with a red plume and a mantle of blue upon her shoulders . she addressed the widower as her friend , and he directed her to sit down beside his son , and they were regarded as woman and husband . early on the following morning , she asked for the bow and arrows of those who had been slain by the wicked manito , and went out a - hunting . as soon as she had got out of sight of the lodge , she changed herself into the wood - bird , as she had been before her marriage , and took her flight through the air .

question: why did monedowa appear to not be like the indian people around her ?
answer1: ate but little , and that of a peculiar kind of meat , flavored with berries
answer4: she ate but little , and that of peculiar kind of meat , flavored with berries
text: although game was scarce in the neighborhood of the widower 's lodge , monedowa returned at evening , in her character of a hunter , with two deer . this was her daily practice , and the widower 's family never more lacked for food . it was noticed , however , that monedowa herself ate but little , and that of a peculiar kind of meat , flavored with berries , which , with other circumstances , convinced them that she was not as the indian people around her . in a few days her father - in - law told her that the manito would come to pay them a visit , to see how the young woman , his daughter , prospered . monedowa answered that she should on that day be absent . when the time arrived , she flew upon a tall tree , overlooking the lodge , and took her station there as the wicked manito passed in . the mudjee monedo cast sharp glances at the scaffolds so well laden with meat , and as soon as she had entered , she said , " why , who is it that is furnishing you with meat so plentifully ? " " no one , " he answered , " but my daughter ; she is just beginning to kill deer . " " no , no , " she retorted ; " some one is living with you . " " kaween , no indeed , " replied the widower ; " you are only making sport of my hapless condition . who do you think would come and trouble themselves about me ? " " very well , " answered the manito , " i will go ; but on such a day i will again visit you , and see who it is that furnishes the meat , and whether it is your daughter or not . "

question: what did monedowa tell her husband to do on the day of the visit of the manito ?

text: she had no sooner left the lodge and got out of sight , than the daughter - in - law made her appearance with two more deer . on being made acquainted with the conduct of the manito , " very well , " she said , " i will be at home the next time , to see her . " both the father and the husband urged monedowa to be aware of the manito . they made known to her all of her cruel courses , and assured her that no woman could escape from her power . " no matter , " said monedowa ; " if she invites me to the race - ground , i will not be backward . what follows , may teach her , my father , to show pity on the vanquished , and not to trample on the widower and those who are without mothers . " when the day of the visit of the manito arrived , monedowa told her husband to prepare certain pieces of meat , which she pointed out to him , together with two or three buds of the birch - tree , which she requested him to put in the pot . she directed also that the manito should be hospitably received , as if she had been just the kind - hearted old indian she professed to be . monedowa then dressed herself as a warrior , embellishing her visage with tints of red , to show that she was prepared for either war or peace .
answer5: the manito should be hospitably received

text: she had no sooner left the lodge and got out of sight , than the daughter - in - law made her appearance with two more deer . on being made acquainted with the conduct of the manito , " very well , " she said , " i will be at home the next time , to see her . " both the father and the husband urged monedowa to be aware of the manito . they made known to her all of her cruel courses , and assured her that no woman could escape from her power . " no matter , " said monedowa ; " if she invites me to the race - ground , i will not be backward . what follows , may teach her , my father , to show pity on the vanquished , and not to trample on the widower and those who are without mothers . " when the day of the visit of the manito arrived , monedowa told her husband to prepare certain pieces of meat , which she pointed out to him , together with two or three buds of the birch - tree , which she requested him to put in the pot . she directed also that the manito should be hospitably received , as if she had been just the kind - hearted old indian she professed to be . monedowa then dressed herself as a warrior , embellishing her visage with tints of red , to show that she was prepared for either war or peace .

question: how did the manito feel about her crafty success ?
answer1: pleased
answer4: pleased
text: as soon as the mudjee monedo arrived , she eyed this strange warrior whom she had never seen before ; but she dissembled , as usual , and , with a gentle laugh , said to the widower , " did i not tell you that some one was staying with you , for i knew your daughter was too young to hunt . " the widower excused himself by saying that he did not think it necessary to tell her , inasmuch as she was a manito , and must have known before she asked . the manito was very pleasant with monedowa , and after much other discourse , in a gentle - spoken voice , she invited her to the racing - ground , saying it was a manly amusement , that she would have an excellent chance to meet there with other warriors , and that she should herself be pleased to run with her . monedowa would have excused herself , saying that she knew nothing of running . " why , " replied the mudjee monedo , trembling in every limb as she spoke , " do not you see how old i look , while you are young and full of life . we must at least run a little to amuse others . " " be it so , then , " replied monedowa . " i will oblige you . i will go in the morning . " pleased with her crafty success , the manito would have now taken her leave , but she was pressed to remain and partake of their hospitality . the meal was immediately prepared . but one dish was used .

question: why did the manito cough with great violence ?
answer1: swallowed a grain of the birch - bud
answer4: she swallowed a grain of birch - bud
text: monedowa partook of it first , to show her guest that she need not fear , saying at the same time , " it is a feast , and as we seldom meet , we must eat all that is placed on the dish , as a mark of gratitude to the great spirit for permitting me to kill animals , and for the pleasure of seeing you , and partaking of it with you . " they ate and talked , on this and that , until they had nearly dispatched the meal , when the manito took up the dish and drank off the broth at a breath . on setting it down she immediately turned her head and commenced coughing with great violence . the old body in which she had disguised herself was well - nigh shaken in pieces , for she had , as monedowa expected , swallowed a grain of the birch - bud , and this , which relished to herself as being of the bird nature , greatly distressed the old manito , who partook of the character of an animal , or four - footed thing . she was at last put to such confusion of face by her constant coughing , that she was enforced to leave , saying , or rather hiccoughing as she left the lodge , that she should look for the young woman at the racing - ground in the morning . when the morning came , monedowa was early astir , oiling her limbs and enameling her breast and arms with red and blue , resembling the plumage in which she had first appeared to minda . upon her brow she placed a tuft of feathers of the same shining tints .

question: what happened to the manito after she drank off the broth at a breath ?
answer1: turned her head and commenced coughing with great violence
answer4: the old body in which she had disguised herself was well - nigh shaken in pieces

question: who attended monedowa to the manito 's racing - ground ?
answer1: minda
answer4: minda , the other and his young daughter
text: by her invitation her husband , minda , the father and his young daughter , attended monedowa to the manito 's racing - ground . the lodge of the manito stood upon a high ground , and near it stretched out a long row of other lodges , said to be possessed by wicked kindred of hers , who shared in the spoils of her cruelty . as soon as the young hunter and her party approached , the inmates appeared at their lodge - doors and cried out : " we are visited . " at this cry , the mudjee monedo came forth and descended with her companions to the starting - post on the plain . from this the course could be seen , winding in a long girdle about the lake ; and as they were now all assembled , the old manito began to speak of the race , belted herself up and pointed to the post , which was an upright pillar of stone . " but before we start , " said the manito , " i wish it to be understood that when women run with me i make a wager , and i expect them to abide by it - life against life . " " very well - be it so , " answered monedowa . " we shall see whose head is to be dashed against the stone . " " we shall , " rejoined the mudjee monedo . " i am very old , but i shall try and make a run . " " very well , " again rejoined monedowa ; " i hope we shall both stand to our bargain . "

question: what did the manito tell monedowa before the race began ?
answer1: " i wish it to be understood that when women run with me i make a wager , and i expect them to abide by it - life against life . "
answer4: i wish it to be understood that when women run with me i make a wager , and i expect them to abide by it - life against life

question: why did monedowa change to a bird when the old manito changed herself into a fox ?
answer1: birds were faster than foxes .
answer4: because she is faster as a bird
text: " good ! " said the old manito ; and she at the same time cast a sly glance at the young hunter , and rolled her eyes toward where stood the pillar of stone . " i am ready , " said monedowa . the starting shout was given , and they set off at high speed , the manito leading , and monedowa pressing closely after . as she closed upon her , the old manito began to show her power , and changing herself into a fox she passed the young hunter with ease , and went leisurely along . monedowa now , with a glance upward , took the shape of the strange bird of red and deep - blue plumage , and with one flight , lighting at some distance ahead of the manito , resumed her mortal shape . when the mudjee monedo espied her competitor before her , " whoa ! whoa ! " she exclaimed ; " this is strange ; " and she immediately changed herself into a wolf , and sped past monedowa . as she galloped by , monedowa heard a noise from her throat , and she knew that she was still in distress from the birch - bud which she had swallowed at her father - in - law 's lodge . monedowa again took wing , and , shooting into the air , she descended suddenly with great swiftness , and took the path far ahead of the old manito . as she passed the wolf she whispered in her ear : " my friend , is this the extent of your speed ? "
answer5: the bird is faster than the fox
answer6: becoming a bird put her ahead of manito

question: what did the old manito assume the shape of to overtake monedowa ?
answer1: the buffalo
answer4: the shape of a deer
text: the manito began to be troubled with bad forebodings , for , on looking ahead , she saw the young hunter in her own manly form , running along at leisure . the mudjee monedo , seeing the necessity of more speed , now passed monedowa in the shape of a deer . they were now far around the circle of the lake , and fast closing in upon the starting - post , when monedowa , putting on her red and blue plumage , glided along the air and alighted upon the track far in advance . to overtake her , the old manito assumed the shape of the buffalo ; and she pushed on with such long gallops that she was again the foremost on the course . the buffalo was the last change she could make , and it was in this form that she had most frequently conquered . the young hunter , once more a bird , in the act of passing the manito , saw her tongue lolling from her mouth with fatigue . " my friend , " said monedowa , " is this all your speed ? " the manito made no answer . monedowa had resumed her character of a hunter , and was within a run of the winning - post , when the wicked manito had nearly overtaken her .

question: what happened to the wicked manito 's kindred ?
answer1: raised a cry of fear and fled away in a body to some distant land
answer4: raised a cry of fear and ffled away in a body to some distant land , whence they have never returned
text: " bakah ! bakah ! nejee ! " she called out to monedowa ; " stop , my friend , i wish to talk to you . " monedowa laughed aloud as she replied : " i will speak to you at the starting - post . when women run with me i make a wager , and i expect them to abide by it - life against life . " one more flight as the blue bird with red wings , and monedowa was so near to the goal that she could easily reach it in her mortal shape . shining in beauty , her face lighted up like the sky , with tinted arms and bosom gleaming in the sun , and the parti - colored plume on her brow waving in the wind . monedowa , cheered by a joyful shout from her own people , leaped to the post . the manito came on with fear in her face . " my friend , " she said , " spare my life ; " and then added , in a low voice , as if she would not that the others should hear it , " give me to live . " and she began to move off as if the request had been granted . " as you have done to others , " replied monedowa , " so shall it be done to you . " and seizing the wicked manito , she dashed her against the pillar of stone . her kindred , who were looking on in horror , raised a cry of fear and fled away in a body to some distant land , whence they have never returned .

question: why did monedowa say she and her husband must leave the widower ?
answer1: she had done that for which she was sent .
answer4: she has done that for which she was sent and is permitted tot ake with her the one whom she loves
text: the widower 's family left the scene , and when they had all come out into the open fields , they walked on together until they had reached the fragrant bank and the evergreen wood , where the son had first encountered his bird lover . monedowa turning to him , said : " my father , here we must part . your son and myself must now leave you . the good spirit , moved with pity , has allowed me to be your friend . i have done that for which i was sent . i am permitted to take with me the one whom i love . i have found your son ever kind , gentle and just . he shall be my companion . the blessing of the good spirit be ever with you . farewell , my father - my sister , farewell . " while the widower man was still lost in wonder at these words , monedowa , and minda her husband , changed at the same moment , rose into the air , as beautiful birds , clothed in shining colors of red and blue .

question: why did monedowa take the widower 's son with her ?
answer1: she was allowed to take one person with her .
answer4: she loved him
text: he had come to a bank , painted with flowers of every hue , and was reclining on its fragrant couch , when a bird , of red and deep - blue plumage softly blended , alighted on a branch near by , and began to pour forth its carol . it was a bird of strange character , such as he had never before seen . it s first note was so delicious to the ear of minda , and it so pierced to his young heart , that he listened as he had never before to any mortal or heavenly sound . it seemed like the human voice , forbidden to speak , and uttering its language through this wild wood - chant with a mournful melody , as if it bewailed the lack of the power or the right to make itself more plainly intelligible . the voice of the bird rose and fell , and circled round and round , but whithersoever floated or spread out its notes , they seemed ever to have their center where minda sat ; and he looked with sad eyes into the sad eyes of the mournful bird , that sat in her red and deep - blue plumage just opposite to the flowery bank . the poor bird strove more and more with her voice , and seemed ever more and more anxiously to address her notes of lament to minda 's ear , till at last he could not refrain from saying , " what aileth thee , sad bird ? " as if she had but waited to be spoken to , the bird left her branch , and alighting upon the bank , smiled on minda , and , shaking her shining plumage , answered : " i am bound in this condition until a maiden shall accept me in marriage . i have wandered these groves and sung to many and many of the indian boys , but none ever heeded my voice till you . will you be mine ? " she added , and poured forth a flood of melody which sparkled and spread itself with its sweet murmurs over all the scene , and fairly entranced the young minda , who sat silent , as if he feared to break the charm by speech . the bird , approaching nearer , asked him , if he loved her , to get his father 's consent to their marriage . " i shall be free then , " said the bird , " and you shall know me as i am . " minda lingered , and listened to the sweet voice of the bird in its own forest notes , or filling each pause with gentle human discourse ; questioning him as to his home , his family , and the little incidents of his daily life . he returned to the lodge later than usual , but he was too timid to speak to his father of that which the bird had charged him . he returned again and again to the fragrant haunt in the wood ; and everyday he listened to the song and the discourse of his bird admirer with more pleasure , and she every day besought him to speak to his father of the marriage . this he could not , however , muster heart and courage to do . the widower 's family left the scene , and when they had all come out into the open fields , they walked on together until they had reached the fragrant bank and the evergreen wood , where the son had first encountered his bird lover . monedowa turning to him , said : " my father , here we must part . your son and myself must now leave you . the good spirit , moved with pity , has allowed me to be your friend . i have done that for which i was sent . i am permitted to take with me the one whom i love . i have found your son ever kind , gentle and just . he shall be my companion . the blessing of the good spirit be ever with you . farewell , my father - my sister , farewell . " while the widower man was still lost in wonder at these words , monedowa , and minda her husband , changed at the same moment , rose into the air , as beautiful birds , clothed in shining colors of red and blue .

question: why did all of the indian fathers abhor the manito ?
answer1: the manito killed their daughters .
answer4: she would challenge and kill their daughters
text: her secret object in these friendly visits was to learn whether the young girls were getting old enough to run with her ; she kept a very sharp eye upon their growth , and the day she thought them ready , she did not fail to challenge them to a trial on her racing - ground . there was not a family in all that beautiful region which had not in this way been visited and thinned out ; and the manito had quite naturally come to be held in abhorrence by all the indian fathers in the country . it happened that there lived near her a poor widower man , whose wife and seven daughters she had made way with ; and he was now living with an only son , and a daughter of ten or twelve years old . this widower was very poor and feeble , and he suffered so much for lack of food and other comforts of the lodge , that he would have been glad to die , but for his son and his little daughter . the mudjee monedo had already visited his lodge to observe whether the girl was sufficiently grown to be challenged to the race ; and so crafty in her approaches and so soft in her manners was the monedo , that the father feared that she would yet decoy the daughter and make way with her as she had done with her mother and her seven sisters , in spite of all his struggles to save her .
answer3: the manito pressured their daughters to shame .

question: why did the old man strive to strengthen his daughter in every good course ?
answer1: he wanted her to grow to be a good woman .
answer4: to not lose the skill and craft of her mother and her sisters
text: and yet he strove with all his might to strengthen his daughter in every good course . he taught her , as best he could , what was becoming for the wise hunter and the brave warrior . he remembered and set before her all that he could recall of the skill and the craft of her mother and her sisters who were lost . the widower man also instructed his son in whatever could make him useful as a husband ; and in the leisure - time of the lodge , he gave his lessons in the art of working with the quills of porcupine , and bestowed on his such other accomplishments as should make him an ornament and a blessing to his wife 's household . the son , minda by name , was kind and obedient to his father , and never failed in his duty . their lodge stood high up on the banks of a lake , which gave them a wide prospect of country , embellished with groves and open fields , which waved with the blue light of their long grass , and made , at all hours of sun and moon , a cheerful scene to look upon . across this beautiful prairie , minda had one morning made his way to gather dry limbs for their fire ; for he disdained no labor of the lodge . and while enjoying the sweetness of the air and the green beauty of the woods , he strolled far away .
answer2: he did not want her to die .
answer3: he wanted to prepare her for the manito 's bet .

question: where did minda return again and again ?
answer1: the fragrant haunt in the wood
answer4: to the fragrant haunt in the wood
text: as if she had but waited to be spoken to , the bird left her branch , and alighting upon the bank , smiled on minda , and , shaking her shining plumage , answered : " i am bound in this condition until a maiden shall accept me in marriage . i have wandered these groves and sung to many and many of the indian boys , but none ever heeded my voice till you . will you be mine ? " she added , and poured forth a flood of melody which sparkled and spread itself with its sweet murmurs over all the scene , and fairly entranced the young minda , who sat silent , as if he feared to break the charm by speech . the bird , approaching nearer , asked him , if he loved her , to get his father 's consent to their marriage . " i shall be free then , " said the bird , " and you shall know me as i am . " minda lingered , and listened to the sweet voice of the bird in its own forest notes , or filling each pause with gentle human discourse ; questioning him as to his home , his family , and the little incidents of his daily life . he returned to the lodge later than usual , but he was too timid to speak to his father of that which the bird had charged him . he returned again and again to the fragrant haunt in the wood ; and everyday he listened to the song and the discourse of his bird admirer with more pleasure , and she every day besought him to speak to his father of the marriage . this he could not , however , muster heart and courage to do .

answer1: to break the spell
answer4: none ever heeded her voice till minda
