question: why did the mudjee monedo invite monedowa to a run ?
answer1: to kill her
answer4: she enjoyed racing people and taking their lives
text: in a region of country where the forest and the prairie strived which should be the most beautiful - the open plain , with its free sunshine and winds and flowers , or the close wood , with its delicious twilight - walks and enamored haunts - there lived a wicked manito in the disguise of an old indian . although the country furnished an abundance of game , and whatever else a good heart could wish for , it was the study of this wicked genius to destroy such as fell into her hands . she made use of all her arts to decoy women into her power , for the purpose of killing them . the country had been once thickly peopled , but this mudjee monedo had so thinned it by her cruel practices , that she now lived almost solitary in the wilderness . the secret of her success lay in her great speed . she had the power to assume the shape of any four - footed creature , and it was her custom to challenge such as she sought to destroy , to run with her . she had a beaten path on which she ran , leading around a large lake , and she always ran around this circle so that the starting and the winning - post was the same . as soon as the mudjee monedo arrived , she eyed this strange warrior whom she had never seen before ; but she dissembled , as usual , and , with a gentle laugh , said to the widower , " did i not tell you that some one was staying with you , for i knew your daughter was too young to hunt . " the widower excused himself by saying that he did not think it necessary to tell her , inasmuch as she was a manito , and must have known before she asked . the manito was very pleasant with monedowa , and after much other discourse , in a gentle - spoken voice , she invited her to the racing - ground , saying it was a manly amusement , that she would have an excellent chance to meet there with other warriors , and that she should herself be pleased to run with her . monedowa would have excused herself , saying that she knew nothing of running . " why , " replied the mudjee monedo , trembling in every limb as she spoke , " do not you see how old i look , while you are young and full of life . we must at least run a little to amuse others . " " be it so , then , " replied monedowa . " i will oblige you . i will go in the morning . " pleased with her crafty success , the manito would have now taken her leave , but she was pressed to remain and partake of their hospitality . the meal was immediately prepared . but one dish was used .
answer5: her cruel practice is to race women
answer3: the mudjee monedo was a trickster .

answer1: to catch the manito off - guard
answer4: she was going to weaken her with a birch - bud

text: there was once a poor man that had three sons , and one day the eldest said , " father , bake my cake and kill my cock till i go seek my fortune . " so he did , and when all was ready , says his father to him , " which will you have -- half of these with my blessing , or the whole with my curse ? " " curse or no curse , " says he , " the whole is little enough . " so away he set , and if the father did not give him his curse , he did not give him his blessing . he walked , and he walked , till he was tired and hungry , and then he sat down to take his dinner . while he was eating it a poor man came up , and asked for a bit . " the dickens a bit you l ll get from me , " says he ; " it 's all too little for myself . " and the poor man walked away very sorrowful . at nightfall he got lodging at a farmer 's , and the man of the house told him that he d 'd give him a spadeful of gold and a shovelful of silver if he d 'd only sit up and watch his daughter 's corpse that was waking in the next room . he said he 'd do that , and so , when the family were in their bed , he sat by the fire , and cast an eye from time to time on the corpse that was lying under the table . all at once the dead woman got up in her shroud , and stood before him , and said , " all alone , fair maid ? " he gave her no answer ; when she had said it the third time she struck him with a switch , and he became a grey flag .

question: who spent all his days in looking after his farm with the help of his nephew tephany ?

answer4: barbaik bourhis
text: in the old land of brittany , once called cornwall , there lived a man named barbaik bourhis , who spent all his days in looking after his farm with the help of his nephew tephany . early and late the two might be seen in the fields or in the dairy , milking cows , making butter , feeding fowls ; working hard themselves and taking care that others worked too . perhaps it might have been better for barbaik if he had left himself a little time to rest and to think about other things , for soon he grew to love money for its own sake , and only gave himself and tephany the food and clothes they absolutely needed . and as for poor people he positively hated them , and declared that such lazy creatures had no business in the world .

question: who was nothing more than a day labourer from the village of plover ?
answer1: young denis
answer4: young denis
text: well , this being the sort of person barbaik was , it is easy to guess at his anger when one day he found tephany talking outside the cowhouse to young denis , who was nothing more than a day labourer from the village of plover . seizing his nephew by the arm , he pulled him sharply away , exclaiming : ' are you not ashamed , boy , to waste your time over a woman who is as poor as a rat , when there are a dozen more who would be only too happy to buy you rings of silver , if you would let them ? ' ' denis is a good workman , as you know very well , ' answered tephany , red with anger , ' and she puts by money too , and soon she will be able to take a farm for herself . ' ' nonsense , ' cried barbaik , ' she will never save enough for a farm till she is a hundred . i would sooner see you in your grave than the husband of a woman who carries her whole fortune on her back . ' ' what does fortune matter when one is young and strong ? ' asked tephany , but his uncle , amazed at such words , would hardly let his finish . ' what does fortune matter ? ' repeated barbaik , in a shocked voice . ' is it possible that you are really so foolish as to despise money ? if this is what you learn from denis , i forbid you to speak to her , and i will have her turned out of the farm if she dares to show her face here again . now go and wash the clothes and spread them out to dry . '

text: tephany did not dare to disobey , but with a heavy heart went down the path to the river . ' he is harder than these rocks , ' said the boy to himself , ' yes , a thousand times harder . for the rain at least can at last wear away the stone , but you might cry for ever , and he would never care . talking to denis is the only pleasure i have , and if i am not to see her i may as well enter a convent . ' thinking these thoughts he reached the bank , and began to unfold the large packet of linen that had to be washed . the tap of a stick made him look up , and standing before him he saw a little old man , whose face was strange to him .

question: what did tephany give to the little old man ?
answer1: the small loaf and some bacon
answer4: the small loaf and some bacon intended for his dinner
text: ' you would like to sit down and rest , granny ? ' asked tephany , pushing aside his bundle . ' when the sky is all the roof you have , you rest where you will , ' replied the old man in trembling tones . ' are you so lonely , then ? ' inquired tephany , full of pity . ' have you no friends who would welcome you into their houses ? ' the old man shook his head . ' they all died long , long ago , ' he answered , ' and the only friends i have are strangers with kind hearts . ' the boy did not speak for a moment , then held out the small loaf and some bacon intended for his dinner .

question: why did tephany give food to the little old man ?
answer1: tephany pitied him .
answer4: he felt bad for him
text: ' you would like to sit down and rest , granny ? ' asked tephany , pushing aside his bundle . ' when the sky is all the roof you have , you rest where you will , ' replied the old man in trembling tones . ' are you so lonely , then ? ' inquired tephany , full of pity . ' have you no friends who would welcome you into their houses ? ' the old man shook his head . ' they all died long , long ago , ' he answered , ' and the only friends i have are strangers with kind hearts . ' the boy did not speak for a moment , then held out the small loaf and some bacon intended for his dinner . ' take this , ' he said ; ' to - day at any rate you shall dine well , ' and the old man took it , gazing at tephany the while . ' those who help others deserve to be helped , ' he answered ; ' your eyes are still red because that miser barbaik has forbidden you to speak to the young woman from plover . but cheer up , you are a good boy , and i will give you something that will enable you to see her once every day . ' ' you ? ' cried tephany , stupefied at discovering that the beggar knew all about his affairs , but the old man did not hear him . ' take this long copper pin , ' he went on , ' and every time you stick it in your dress father bourhis will be obliged to leave the house in order to go and count his cabbages . as long as the pin is in your dress you will be free , and your uncle will not come back until you have put it in its case again . ' then , rising , he nodded to tephany and vanished . the boy stood where he was , as still as a stone . if it had not been for the pin in his hands he would have thought he was dreaming . but by that token he knew it was no common old man who had given it to him , but a fairy , wise in telling what would happen in the days to come . then suddenly tephany 's eyes fell on the clothes , and to make up for lost time he began to wash them with great vigour .
answer6: he felt sorry that he had no friends

text: day by day his heart grew heavier and his cheeks paler , and one evening , when he had waited for her in vain , he put his water - pot on his shoulder and went slowly down to the spring . on the path in front of him stood the fairy who had given him the pin , and as he glanced at tephany he gave a little mischievous laugh and said : ' why , my pretty maiden hardly looks happier than he did before , in spite of meeting his lover whenever he pleases . ' ' she has grown tired of me , ' answered tephany in a trembling voice , ' and she makes excuses to stay away . ah ! granny dear , it is not enough to be able to see her , i must be able to amuse her and to keep her with me . she is so clever , you know . help me to be clever too . ' ' is that what you want ? ' cried the old man . ' well , take this feather and stick it in your hair , and you will be as wise as solomon herself . '

question: how did denis feel after tephany spoke so wisely ?
answer1: surprised
answer4: dumbfounded
text: blushing with pleasure tephany went home and stuck the feather into the blue ribbon which boys always wear in that part of the country . in a moment he heard denis whistling gaily , and as his uncle was safely counting his cabbages , he hurried out to meet her . the young woman was struck dumb by his talk . there was nothing that he did not seem to know , and as for songs he not only could sing those from every part of brittany , but could compose them himself . was this really the quiet boy who had been so anxious to learn all she could teach him , or was it somebody else ? perhaps he had gone suddenly mad , and there was an evil spirit inside him . but in any case , night after night she came back , only to find his growing wiser and wiser . soon the neighbours whispered their surprise among themselves , for tephany had not been able to resist the pleasure of putting the feather in his hair for some of the people who despised him for his poor clothes , and many were the jokes he made about them . of course they heard of his jests , and shook their heads saying : ' he is an ill - natured little cat , and the woman that marries him will find that it is he who will hold the reins and drive the horse . ' it was not long before denis began to agree with them , and as she always liked to be mistress wherever she went , she became afraid of tephany 's sharp tongue , and instead of laughing as before when he made fun of other people she grew red and uncomfortable , thinking that her turn would come next .

text: so matters went on till one evening denis told tephany that she really could not stay a moment , as she had promised to go to a dance that was to be held in the next village . tephany 's face fell ; he had worked hard all day , and had been counting on a quiet hour with denis . he did his best to persuade her to remain with him , but she would not listen , and at last he grew angry . ' oh , i know why you are so anxious not to sir the dance , ' he said ; ' it is because aziliez of pennenru will be there . ' now aziliez was the loveliest boy for miles round , and he and denis had known each other from childhood . ' oh yes , aziliez will be there , ' answered denis , who was quite pleased to see him jealous , ' and naturally one would go a long way to watch his dance . ' ' go then ! ' cried tephany , and entering the house he slammed the door behind him .

question: why did tephany regret asking for wisdom ?

text: lonely and miserable he sat down by the fire and stared into the red embers . then , flinging the feather from his hair , he put his head on his hands , and sobbed passionately . ' what is the use of being clever when it is beauty that women want ? that is what i ought to have asked for . but it is too late , denis will never come back . ' ' since you wish it so much you shall have beauty , ' said a voice at his side , and looking round he beheld the old man leaning on his stick . ' fasten this necklace round your neck , and as long as you wear it you will be the most beautiful man in the world , ' continued the fairy . with a little shriek of joy tephany took the necklace , and snapping the clasp ran to the mirror which hung in the corner . ah , this time he was not afraid of aziliez or of any other boy , for surely none could be as fair and white as he . and with the sight of his face a thought came to him , and putting on hastily his best dress and his buckled shoes he hurried off to the dance . on the way he met a beautiful carriage with a young woman seated in it . ' what a lovely maiden ! ' she exclaimed , as tephany approached . ' why , there is not a boy in my own country that can be compared to him . he , and no other , shall be my bridegroom . '

text: the carriage was large and barred the narrow road , so tephany was forced , much against his will , to remain where he was . but he looked the young woman full in the face as he answered : ' go your way , noble lady , and let me go mine . i am only a poor peasant boy , accustomed to milk , and make hay and spin . ' ' peasant you may be , but i will make you a great gentleman , ' said she , taking his hand and trying to lead him to the carriage . ' i do not want to be a great gentleman , i only want to be the husband of denis , ' he replied , throwing off her hand and running to the ditch which divided the road from the cornfield , where she hoped to hide . unluckily the young woman guessed what he was doing , and signed to her attendants , who seized him and put him in the coach . the door was banged , and the horses whipped up into a gallop .

question: where did tephany and the young woman arrive at ?
answer1: a splendid castle
answer4: a splendid castle
text: at the end of an hour they arrived at a splendid castle , and tephany , who would not move , was lifted out and carried into the hall , while a priestess was sent for to perform the marriage ceremony . the young woman tried to win a smile from him by telling of all the beautiful things he should have as her husband , but tephany did not listen to her , and looked about to see if there was any means by which he could escape . it did not seem easy . the three great doors were closely barred , and the one through which he had entered shut with a spring , but his feather was still in his hair , and by its aid he detected a crack in the wooden panelling , through which a streak of light could be dimly seen . touching the copper pin which fastened his dress , the boy sent every one in the hall to count the cabbages , while he himself passed through the little door , not knowing whither he was going . by this time night had fallen , and tephany was very tired . thankfully he found himself at the gate of a convent , and asked if he might stay there till morning . but the portress answered roughly that it was no place for beggars , and bade him begone , so the poor boy dragged himself slowly along the road , till a light and the bark of a dog told him that he was near a farm .

text: at the end of an hour they arrived at a splendid castle , and tephany , who would not move , was lifted out and carried into the hall , while a priestess was sent for to perform the marriage ceremony . the young woman tried to win a smile from him by telling of all the beautiful things he should have as her husband , but tephany did not listen to her , and looked about to see if there was any means by which he could escape . it did not seem easy . the three great doors were closely barred , and the one through which he had entered shut with a spring , but his feather was still in his hair , and by its aid he detected a crack in the wooden panelling , through which a streak of light could be dimly seen . touching the copper pin which fastened his dress , the boy sent every one in the hall to count the cabbages , while he himself passed through the little door , not knowing whither he was going . by this time night had fallen , and tephany was very tired . thankfully he found himself at the gate of a convent , and asked if he might stay there till morning . but the portress answered roughly that it was no place for beggars , and bade him begone , so the poor boy dragged himself slowly along the road , till a light and the bark of a dog told him that he was near a farm .
answer2: he used the feather and the copper pin .

question: where did tephany go to rest ?
answer1: a farm
answer4: a farm
text: in front of the house was a group of people ; two or three men and the daughters of the farmer . when their father heard tephany 's request to be given a bed the good husband 's heart softened , and he was just going to invite him inside , when the young women , whose heads were turned by the boy 's beauty , began to quarrel as to which should do most for him . from words they came to blows , and the men , frightened at the disturbance , pelted tephany with insulting names . he quickly ran down the nearest path , hoping to escape them in the darkness of the trees , but in an instant he heard their footsteps behind him . wild with fear his legs trembled under him , when suddenly he bethought himself of his necklace . with a violent effort he burst the clasp and flung it round the neck of a pig which was grunting in a ditch , and as he did so he heard the footsteps cease from pursuing him and run after the pig , for his charm had vanished . on he went , scarcely knowing where he was going , till he found himself , to his surprise and joy , close to his uncle 's house . for several days he felt so tired and unhappy that he could hardly get through his work , and to make matters worse denis scarcely ever came near him . ' she was too busy , ' she said , ' and really it was only rich people who could afford to waste time in talking . '

text: as the days went on tephany grew paler and paler , till everybody noticed it except his uncle . the water - pot was almost too heavy for him now , but morning and evening he carried it to the spring , though the effort to lift it to his shoulder was often too much for him . ' how could i have been so foolish , ' he whispered to himself , when he went down as usual at sunset . ' it was not freedom to see denis that i should have asked for , for she was soon weary of me , nor a quick tongue , for she was afraid of it , nor beauty , for that brought me nothing but trouble , but riches which make life easy both for oneself and others . ah ! if i only dared to beg this gift from the fairy , i should be wiser than before and know how to choose better . ' ' be satisfied , ' said the voice of the old man , who seemed to be standing unseen at tephany 's elbow . ' if you look in your right - hand pocket when you go home you will find a small box . rub your eyes with the ointment it contains , and you will see that you yourself contain a priceless treasure . '

text: as the days went on tephany grew paler and paler , till everybody noticed it except his uncle . the water - pot was almost too heavy for him now , but morning and evening he carried it to the spring , though the effort to lift it to his shoulder was often too much for him . ' how could i have been so foolish , ' he whispered to himself , when he went down as usual at sunset . ' it was not freedom to see denis that i should have asked for , for she was soon weary of me , nor a quick tongue , for she was afraid of it , nor beauty , for that brought me nothing but trouble , but riches which make life easy both for oneself and others . ah ! if i only dared to beg this gift from the fairy , i should be wiser than before and know how to choose better . ' ' be satisfied , ' said the voice of the old man , who seemed to be standing unseen at tephany 's elbow . ' if you look in your right - hand pocket when you go home you will find a small box . rub your eyes with the ointment it contains , and you will see that you yourself contain a priceless treasure . ' tephany did not in the least understand what he meant , but ran back to the farm as fast as he could , and began to fumble joyfully in his right - hand pocket . sure enough , there was the little box with the precious ointment . he was in the act of rubbing his eyes with it when barbaik bourhis entered the room . ever since he had been obliged to leave his work and pass his time , he did not know why , in counting cabbages , everything had gone wrong , and he could not get a labourer to stay with him because of his bad temper . when , therefore , he saw his nephew standing quietly before his mirror , barbaik broke out : ' so this is what you do when i am out in the fields ! ah ! it is no wonder if the farm is ruined . are you not ashamed , boy , to behave so ? ' tephany tried to stammer some excuse , but his uncle was half mad with rage , and a box on the ears was his only answer . at this tephany , hurt , bewildered and excited , could control himself no longer , and turning away burst into tears . but what was his surprise when he saw that each tear - drop was a round and shining pearl . barbaik , who also beheld this marvel , uttered a cry of astonishment , and threw himself on his knees to pick them up from the floor . he was still gathering them when the door opened and in came denis .

text: ' pearls ! are they really pearls ? ' she asked , falling on her knees also , and looking up at tephany she perceived others still more beautiful rolling down the boy 's cheeks . ' take care not to let any of the neighbours hear of it , denis , ' said barbaik . ' of course you shall have your share , but nobody else shall get a single one . cry on , my dear , cry on , ' he continued to tephany . ' ' then i will go with you , ' said barbaik , who never trusted anyone and was afraid of being cheated . so the two went out , leaving tephany behind them . he sat quite still on his chair , his hands clasped tightly together , as if he was forcing something back . at last he raised his eyes , which had been fixed on the ground , and beheld the fairy standing in a dark corner by the hearth , observing him with a mocking look . the boy trembled and jumped up , then , taking the feather , the pin , and the box , he held them out to the old man .

question: who wandered away from her home and went to emmet village ?
answer1: a scholar
answer4: a scholar
text: once upon a time there was a scholar , who wandered away from her home and went to emmet village . there stood a house which was said to be haunted . yet it was beautifully situated and surrounded by a lovely garden . so the scholar hired it . one evening she was sitting over her books , when several hundred knights suddenly came galloping into the room . they were quite tiny , and their horses were about the size of flies . they had hunting falcons and dogs about as large as gnats and fleas . they came to her bed in the corner of the room , and there they held a great hunt , with bows and arrows : one could see it all quite plainly . they caught a tremendous quantity of birds and game , and all this game was no larger than little grains of rice .

question: who was wearing a scarlet hat and garments of purple ?
answer1: a queen
answer4: a queen
text: the scholar gradually accustomed herself to the sight . although the women were so very small she could distinguish everything quite clearly . before long , a bright colored banner appeared . behind it rode a personage wearing a scarlet hat and garments of purple . she was surrounded by an escort of several thousands . before her went runners with whips and rods to clear the way . then a woman wearing an iron helmet and with a golden ax in her hand cried out in a loud voice : " her highness is graciously pleased to look at the fish in the purple lake ! " whereupon the one who wore the scarlet hat got down from her horse , and , followed by a retinue of several hundred women , approached the saucer which the scholar used for her writing - ink . tents were put up on the edge of the saucer and a banquet was prepared . a great number of guests sat down to the table . musicians and dancers stood ready . there was a bright confusion of mingled garments of purple and scarlet , crimson and green . pipes and flutes , fiddles and cymbals sounded , and the dancers moved in the dance . the music was very faint , and yet its melodies could be clearly distinguished . all that was said , too , the table - talk and orders , questions and calls , could be quite distinctly heard .

text: on a night in mid - autumn , an empress of the tang dynasty once sat at wine with two sorceresses . and one of them took her bamboo staff and cast it into the air , where it turned into a heavenly bridge , on which the three climbed up to the moon together . there they saw a great castle on which was inscribed : " the spreading halls of crystal cold . " beside it stood a cassia tree which blossomed and gave forth a fragrance filling all the air . and in the tree sat a woman who was chopping off the smaller boughs with an ax .

question: who was a very good - natured little fellow , and did her duties so willingly and well that everybody liked her ?
answer1: a little page - girl
answer4: a little page - girl
text: there was once a little page - girl , who was in service in a stately castle . she was a very good - natured little fellow , and did her duties so willingly and well that everybody liked her , from the great earl whom she served every day on bended knee , to the fat old butler whose errands she ran . now the castle stood on the edge of a cliff overlooking the sea , and although the walls at that side were very thick , in them there was a little postern door , which opened on to a narrow flight of steps that led down the face of the cliff to the sea shore , so that anyone who liked could go down there in the pleasant summer mornings and bathe in the shimmering sea . on the other side of the castle were gardens and pleasure grounds , opening on to a long stretch of heather - covered moorland , which , at last , met a distant range of hills .

text: there was once a little page - girl , who was in service in a stately castle . she was a very good - natured little fellow , and did her duties so willingly and well that everybody liked her , from the great earl whom she served every day on bended knee , to the fat old butler whose errands she ran . now the castle stood on the edge of a cliff overlooking the sea , and although the walls at that side were very thick , in them there was a little postern door , which opened on to a narrow flight of steps that led down the face of the cliff to the sea shore , so that anyone who liked could go down there in the pleasant summer mornings and bathe in the shimmering sea . on the other side of the castle were gardens and pleasure grounds , opening on to a long stretch of heather - covered moorland , which , at last , met a distant range of hills .

question: why was the little page - girl very fond of going out on this moor ?
answer1: she could run about as much as she liked , chasing bumble - bees , and catching butterflies , and looking for birds ' nests when it was nesting time .
answer4: she could run about as much as she liked
text: the little page - girl was very fond of going out on this moor when her work was done , for then she could run about as much as she liked , chasing bumble - bees , and catching butterflies , and looking for birds ' nests when it was nesting time . and the old butler was very pleased that she should do so , for she knew that it was good for a healthy little lass to have plenty of fun in the open air . but before the girl went out the old woman always gave her one warning . " now , mind my words , laddie , and keep far away from the fairy knowe , for the little folk are not to trust to . "

question: who would punish any rash mortal who came too near them ?

text: this knowe of which she spoke was a little green hillock , which stood on the moor not twenty yards from the garden gate , and folk said that it was the abode of fairies , who would punish any rash mortal who came too near them . and because of this the country people would walk a good half - mile out of their way , even in broad daylight , rather than run the risk of going too near the fairy knowe and bringing down the little folks ' displeasure upon them . and at night they would hardly cross the moor at all , for everyone knows that fairies come abroad in the darkness , and the door of their dwelling stands open , so that any luckless mortal who does not take care may find herself inside . now , the little page - girl was an adventurous wight , and instead of being frightened of the fairies , she was very anxious to see them , and to visit their abode , just to find out what it was like .

question: who did the little page - girl see after she slipped inside the knowe ?
answer1: the tiny folk , fairies , and elves , and gnomes

text: she found herself in a large room lit by numberless tiny candles , and there , seated round a polished table , were scores of the tiny folk , fairies , and elves , and gnomes , dressed in green , and yellow , and pink ; blue , and lilac , and scarlet ; in all the colours , in fact , that you can think of . she stood in a dark corner watching the busy scene in wonder , thinking how strange it was that there should be such a number of these tiny beings living their own lives all unknown to women , at such a little distance from them , when suddenly someone -- she could not tell who it was -- gave an order . " fetch the cup , " cried the owner of the unknown voice , and instantly two little fairy pages , dressed all in scarlet livery , darted from the table to a tiny cupboard in the rock , and returned staggering under the weight of a most beautiful silver cup , richly embossed and lined inside with gold .

text: she placed it in the middle of the table , and , amid clapping of hands and shouts of joy , all the fairies began to drink out of it in turn . and the page could see , from where she stood , that no one poured wine into it , and yet it was always full , and that the wine that was in it was not always the same kind , but that each fairy , when she grasped its stem , wished for the wine that she loved best , and lo ! in a moment the cup was full of it . " twould be a fine thing if i could take that cup home with me , " thought the page . " no one will believe that i have been here except i have something to show for it . " so she bided her time , and watched . she raised the cup to her lips , but she did not drink from it . with a sudden jerk she threw the water over the candles , and instantly the room was in darkness . then , clasping the precious cup tightly in her arms , she sprang to the opening of the knowe , through which she could see the stars glimmering clearly . she was just in time , for it fell to with a crash behind her ; and soon she was speeding along the wet , dew - spangled moor , with the whole troop of fairies at her heels . they were wild with rage , and from the shrill shouts of fury which they uttered , the page knew well that , if they overtook her , she need expect no mercy at their hands . and her heart began to sink , for , fleet of foot though she was , she was no match for the fairy folk , who gained on her steadily .

text: she placed it in the middle of the table , and , amid clapping of hands and shouts of joy , all the fairies began to drink out of it in turn . and the page could see , from where she stood , that no one poured wine into it , and yet it was always full , and that the wine that was in it was not always the same kind , but that each fairy , when she grasped its stem , wished for the wine that she loved best , and lo ! in a moment the cup was full of it . " twould be a fine thing if i could take that cup home with me , " thought the page . " no one will believe that i have been here except i have something to show for it . " so she bided her time , and watched . presently the fairies noticed her , and , instead of being angry at her boldness in entering their abode , as she expected that they would be , they seemed very pleased to see her , and invited her to a seat at the table . but by and by they grew rude and insolent , and jeered at her for being content to serve mere mortals , telling her that they saw everything that went on at the castle , and making fun of the old butler , whom the page loved with all her heart . and they laughed at the food she ate , saying that it was only fit for animals ; and when any fresh dainty was set on the table by the scarlet - clad pages , they would push the dish across to her , saying : " taste it , for you will not have the chance of tasting such things at the castle . " at last she could stand their teasing remarks no longer ; besides , she knew that if she wanted to secure the cup she must lose no time in doing so . so she suddenly stood up , and grasped the stem of it tightly in her hand . " i l ll drink to you all in water , " she cried , and instantly the ruby wine was turned to clear cold water .

" how happy we were there , " they said to each other . then the spring came , and all over the country there were little blossoms and little birds . only in the garden of the selfish giant it was still winter . the birds did not care to sing in it as there were no children , and the trees forgot to blossom . once a beautiful flower put its head out from the grass , but when it saw the notice - board it was so sorry for the children that it slipped back into the ground again , and went off to sleep . the only people who were pleased were the snow and the frost .

question: why did n't spring come in the giant 's garden ?
answer1: the children were n't there .

text: but the spring never came , nor the summer . the autumn gave golden fruit to every garden , but to the giant 's garden he gave none . " she is too selfish , " he said . so it was always winter there , and the north wind , and the hail , and the frost , and the snow danced about through the trees . one morning the giant was lying awake in bed when she heard some lovely music . it sounded so sweet to her ears that she thought it must be the queen 's musicians passing by . it was really only a little linnet singing outside her window , but it was so long since she had heard a bird sing in her garden that it seemed to her to be the most beautiful music in the world . then the hail stopped dancing over her head , and the north wind ceased roaring , and a delicious perfume came to her through the open casement . " i believe the spring has come at last , " said the giant ; and she jumped out of bed and looked out . what did she see ? she saw a most wonderful sight . through a little hole in the wall the children had crept in , and they were sitting in the branches of the trees . in every tree that she could see there was a little child . and the trees were so glad to have the children back again that they had covered themselves with blossoms , and were waving their arms gently above the children 's heads . the birds were flying about and twittering with delight , and the flowers were looking up through the green grass and laughing . it was a lovely scene , only in one corner it was still winter . it was the farthest corner of the garden , and in it was standing a little girl . she was so small that she could not reach up to the branches of the tree , and she was wandering all round it , crying bitterly . the poor tree was still quite covered with frost and snow , and the north wind was blowing and roaring above it .

text: " climb up ! little girl , " said the tree , and it bent its branches down as low as it could ; but the girl was too tiny . and the giant 's heart melted as she looked out . " how selfish i have been ! " she said ; " now i know why the spring would not come here . i will put that poor little girl on the top of the tree , and then i will knock down the wall , and my garden shall be the children 's playground for ever and ever . " she was really very sorry for what she had done . so she crept downstairs and opened the front door quite softly , and went out into the garden . but when the children saw her they were so frightened that they all ran away , and the garden became winter again . only the little girl did not run , for her eyes were so full of tears that she did not see the giant coming . and the giant stole up behind her and took her gently in her hand , and put her up into the tree .

question: why was the giant selfish ?
answer1: she did not allow anybody to play in her garden but herself .
answer4: she did not allow nobody to play in her garden but herself .
text: one day the giant came back . she had been to visit her friend the cornish ogre , and had stayed with her for seven years . after the seven years were over she had said all that she had to say , for her conversation was limited , and she determined to return to her own castle . when she arrived she saw the children playing in the garden . " what are you doing here ? " she cried in a very gruff voice , and the children ran away . " my own garden is my own garden , " said the giant ; " any one can understand that , and i will allow nobody to play in it but myself . " so she built a high wall all round it , and put up a notice - board . she was a very selfish giant . the poor children had now nowhere to play . they tried to play on the road , but the road was very dusty and full of hard stones , and they did not like it . they used to wander round the high wall when their lessons were over , and talk about the beautiful garden inside . " how happy we were there , " they said to each other . then the spring came , and all over the country there were little blossoms and little birds . only in the garden of the selfish giant it was still winter . the birds did not care to sing in it as there were no children , and the trees forgot to blossom . once a beautiful flower put its head out from the grass , but when it saw the notice - board it was so sorry for the children that it slipped back into the ground again , and went off to sleep . the only people who were pleased were the snow and the frost .
answer5: she built a high wall all round her garden , and put up a notice board .

question: why was the giant sorry for what she had done ?
answer1: she realized that she was selfish .
answer4: she saw how beautiful her garden was whe children played in it .
text: but the spring never came , nor the summer . the autumn gave golden fruit to every garden , but to the giant 's garden he gave none . " she is too selfish , " he said . so it was always winter there , and the north wind , and the hail , and the frost , and the snow danced about through the trees . one morning the giant was lying awake in bed when she heard some lovely music . it sounded so sweet to her ears that she thought it must be the queen 's musicians passing by . it was really only a little linnet singing outside her window , but it was so long since she had heard a bird sing in her garden that it seemed to her to be the most beautiful music in the world . then the hail stopped dancing over her head , and the north wind ceased roaring , and a delicious perfume came to her through the open casement . " i believe the spring has come at last , " said the giant ; and she jumped out of bed and looked out . what did she see ? she saw a most wonderful sight . through a little hole in the wall the children had crept in , and they were sitting in the branches of the trees . in every tree that she could see there was a little child . and the trees were so glad to have the children back again that they had covered themselves with blossoms , and were waving their arms gently above the children 's heads . the birds were flying about and twittering with delight , and the flowers were looking up through the green grass and laughing . it was a lovely scene , only in one corner it was still winter . it was the farthest corner of the garden , and in it was standing a little girl . she was so small that she could not reach up to the branches of the tree , and she was wandering all round it , crying bitterly . the poor tree was still quite covered with frost and snow , and the north wind was blowing and roaring above it . " climb up ! little girl , " said the tree , and it bent its branches down as low as it could ; but the girl was too tiny . and the giant 's heart melted as she looked out . " how selfish i have been ! " she said ; " now i know why the spring would not come here . i will put that poor little girl on the top of the tree , and then i will knock down the wall , and my garden shall be the children 's playground for ever and ever . " she was really very sorry for what she had done . so she crept downstairs and opened the front door quite softly , and went out into the garden . but when the children saw her they were so frightened that they all ran away , and the garden became winter again . only the little girl did not run , for her eyes were so full of tears that she did not see the giant coming . and the giant stole up behind her and took her gently in her hand , and put her up into the tree .
answer2: the garden turned beautiful when the children came .
answer3: spring came when the children played in the garden .

text: long , long ago in japan there lived an old woman and her husband . the old woman was a good , kind - hearted , hard - working old fellow , but her husband was a regular cross - patch , who spoiled the happiness of his home by his scolding tongue . he was always grumbling about something from morning to night . the old woman had for a long time ceased to take any notice of his crossness . she was out most of the day at work in the fields , and as she had no child , for her amusement when she came home , she kept a tame sparrow . she loved the little bird just as much as if he had been her child .

text: now one day the old woman went out to chop wood in the forest , and the old man stopped at home to wash clothes . the day before , he had made some starch , and now when he came to look for it , it was all gone ; the bowl which he had filled full yesterday was quite empty . while he was wondering who could have used or stolen the starch , down flew the pet sparrow , and bowing his little feathered head - a trick which he had been taught by his mistress - the pretty bird chirped and said : " it is i who have taken the starch . i thought it was some food put out for me in that basin , and i ate it all . if i have made a mistake i beg you to forgive me ! tweet , tweet , tweet ! question: why did the man not forgive the sparrow ?
answer1: the old man had never loved the sparrow .

text: you see from this that the sparrow was a truthful bird , and the old man ought to have been willing to forgive him at once when he asked his pardon so nicely . but not so . the old man had never loved the sparrow , and had often quarreled with his wife for keeping what he called a dirty bird about the house , saying that it only made extra work for him . now he was only too delighted to have some cause of complaint against the pet . he scolded and even cursed the poor little bird for his bad behavior , and not content with using these harsh , unfeeling words , in a fit of rage he seized the sparrow - who all this time had spread out his wings and bowed his head before the old man , to show how sorry he was - and fetched the scissors and cut off the poor little bird 's tongue .

text: in the evening the old woman came home . as usual , on the way back she looked forward to the time when she should reach her gate and see her pet come flying and chirping to meet her , ruffling out his feathers to show his joy , and at last coming to rest on her shoulder . but to - night the old woman was very disappointed , for not even the shadow of her dear sparrow was to be seen . she quickened her steps , hastily drew off her straw sandals , and stepped on to the veranda . still no sparrow was to be seen . she now felt sure that her husband , in one of his cross tempers , had shut the sparrow up in its cage . so she called him and said anxiously : " where is suzume san ( sir sparrow ) today ? "

text: the old man pretended not to know at first , and answered : " your sparrow ? i am sure i do not know . now i come to think of it , i have not seen him all the afternoon . i should not wonder if the ungrateful bird had flown away and left you after all your petting ! " but at last , when the old woman gave him no peace , but asked him again and again , insisting that he must know what had happened to her pet , he confessed all . he told her crossly how the sparrow had eaten the rice - paste he had specially made for starching his clothes , and how when the sparrow had confessed to what he had done , in great anger he had taken his scissors and cut out his tongue , and how finally he had driven the bird away and forbidden him to return to the house again .

text: she never stopped to rest for her noonday meal , and it was far on in the afternoon when she found herself near a large bamboo wood . bamboo groves are the favorite haunts of sparrows , and there sure enough at the edge of the wood she saw her own dear sparrow waiting to welcome her . she could hardly believe her eyes for joy , and ran forward quickly to greet him . he bowed his little head and went through a number of the tricks his mistress had taught him , to show his pleasure at seeing his old friend again , and , wonderful to relate , he could talk as of old . the old woman told him how sorry she was for all that had happened , and inquired after his tongue , wondering how he could speak so well without it . then the sparrow opened his beak and showed her that a new tongue had grown in place of the old one , and begged her not to think any more about the past , for he was quite well now . then the old woman knew that her sparrow was a fairy , and no common bird . it would be difficult to exaggerate the old woman 's rejoicing now . she forgot all her troubles , she forgot even how tired she was , for she had found her lost sparrow , and instead of being ill and without a tongue as she had feared and expected to find him , he was well and happy and with a new tongue , and without a sign of the ill - treatment he had received from her husband . and above all he was a fairy .

text: she never stopped to rest for her noonday meal , and it was far on in the afternoon when she found herself near a large bamboo wood . bamboo groves are the favorite haunts of sparrows , and there sure enough at the edge of the wood she saw her own dear sparrow waiting to welcome her . she could hardly believe her eyes for joy , and ran forward quickly to greet him . he bowed his little head and went through a number of the tricks his mistress had taught him , to show his pleasure at seeing his old friend again , and , wonderful to relate , he could talk as of old . the old woman told him how sorry she was for all that had happened , and inquired after his tongue , wondering how he could speak so well without it . then the sparrow opened his beak and showed her that a new tongue had grown in place of the old one , and begged her not to think any more about the past , for he was quite well now . then the old woman knew that her sparrow was a fairy , and no common bird . it would be difficult to exaggerate the old woman 's rejoicing now . she forgot all her troubles , she forgot even how tired she was , for she had found her lost sparrow , and instead of being ill and without a tongue as she had feared and expected to find him , he was well and happy and with a new tongue , and without a sign of the ill - treatment he had received from her husband . and above all he was a fairy .

text: the sparrow asked her to follow him , and flying before her he led her to a beautiful house in the heart of the bamboo grove . the old woman was utterly astonished when she entered the house to find what a beautiful place it was . it was built of the whitest wood , the soft cream - colored mats which took the place of carpets were the finest she had ever seen , and the cushions that the sparrow brought out for her to sit on were made of the finest silk and crape . beautiful vases and lacquer boxes adorned the tokonoma of every room .

question: why did the sparrow thank the old woman ?
answer1: for all the kindness she had shown him for many long years

text: the sparrow led the old woman to the place of honor , and then , taking his place at a humble distance , he thanked her with many polite bows for all the kindness she had shown him for many long years . then the gentleman sparrow , as we will now call him , introduced all his family to the old woman . this done , his sons , robed in dainty crape gowns , brought in on beautiful old - fashioned trays a feast of all kinds of delicious foods , till the old woman began to think she must be dreaming . in the middle of the dinner some of the sparrow 's sons performed a wonderful dance , called the " suzume - odori " or the " sparrow 's dance , " to amuse the guest .

question: what happened because the old woman enjoyed herself so much ?

answer4: the hours flew by too quickly
text: never had the old woman enjoyed herself so much . the hours flew by too quickly in this lovely spot , with all these fairy sparrows to wait upon her and to feast her and to dance before her . but the night came on and the darkness reminded her that she had a long way to go and must think about taking her leave and return home . she thanked her kind host for his splendid entertainment , and begged him for her sake to forget all he had suffered at the hands of her cross old husband . she told the gentleman sparrow that it was a great comfort and happiness to her to find him in such a beautiful home and to know that he wanted for nothing . it was her anxiety to know how he fared and what had really happened to him that had led her to seek him . now she knew that all was well she could return home with a light heart . if ever he wanted her for anything he had only to send for her and she would come at once .

text: the gentleman sparrow begged her to stay and rest several days and enjoy the change , but the old woman said she must return to her old husband - who would probably be cross at hers not coming home at the usual time - and to her work , and there - fore , much as she wished to do so , she could not accept his kind invitation . but now that she knew where the gentleman sparrow lived she would come to see him whenever she had the time . when the gentleman sparrow saw that he could not persuade the old woman to stay longer , he gave an order to some of his servants , and they at once brought in two boxes , one large and the other small . these were placed before the old woman , and the gentleman sparrow asked her to choose whichever she liked for a present , which he wished to give her .

question: why did the old woman choose the smaller box ?
answer1: she was too old and feeble to carry the big and heavy box .
answer4: she is now too old and feeble to carry the big and heavy box
text: the old woman could not refuse this kind proposal , and she chose the smaller box , saying : " i am now too old and feeble to carry the big and heavy box . as you are so kind as to say that i may take whichever i like , i will choose the small one , which will be easier for me to carry . " then the sparrows all helped her put it on her back and went to the gate to see her off , bidding her good - by with many bows and entreating her to come again whenever she had the time . thus the old woman and her pet sparrow separated quite happily , the sparrow showing not the least ill - will for all the unkindness he had suffered at the hands of the old husband . indeed , he only felt sorrow for the old woman who had to put up with it all her life .

text: when the old woman reached home she found her husband even crosser than usual , for it was late on in the night and he had been waiting up for her for a long time . text: " now let us see what is in the box , " said the old woman , not giving his time to grumble again . " you must help me open it . " many times . but the old man , after the first moments of surprise and satisfaction at the sight of the gold and silver were over , could not suppress the greed of his wicked nature . he now began to reproach the old woman for not having brought home the big box of presents , for in the innocence of her heart she had told him how she had refused the large box of presents which the sparrows had offered her , preferring the smaller one because it was light and easy to carry home . question: why did the old man not deserve the good luck that had befallen them ?
answer1: he was greedy and mean .
answer4: he is a greedy old man
text: you see from this that the sparrow was a truthful bird , and the old man ought to have been willing to forgive him at once when he asked his pardon so nicely . but not so . the old man had never loved the sparrow , and had often quarreled with his wife for keeping what he called a dirty bird about the house , saying that it only made extra work for him . now he was only too delighted to have some cause of complaint against the pet . he scolded and even cursed the poor little bird for his bad behavior , and not content with using these harsh , unfeeling words , in a fit of rage he seized the sparrow - who all this time had spread out his wings and bowed his head before the old man , to show how sorry he was - and fetched the scissors and cut off the poor little bird 's tongue . the old woman now wished that she had said nothing about the big box , but it was too late ; the greedy old man , not contented with the good luck which had so unexpectedly befallen them and which he so little deserved , made up his mind , if possible , to get more . early the next morning he got up and made the old woman describe the way to the sparrow 's house . when she saw what was in his mind she tried to keep him from going , but it was useless . he would not listen to one word she said . it is strange that the old man did not feel ashamed of going to see the sparrow after the cruel way he had treated him in cutting off his tongue in a fit of rage . but his greed to get the big box made him forget everything else . it did not even enter his thoughts that the sparrows might be angry with him - as , indeed , they were - and might punish him for what he had done .
answer2: he had cut the sparrow 's tongue .

question: how did gentleman sparrow 's family feel about the old man ?
answer1: dislike

text: ever since the gentleman sparrow had returned home in the sad plight in which they had first found him , weeping and bleeding from the mouth , his whole family and relations had done little else but speak of the cruelty of the old man . " how could he , " they asked each other , " inflict such a heavy punishment for such a trifling offense as that of eating some rice - paste by mistake ? " they all loved the old woman who was so kind and good and patient under all her troubles , but the old man they hated , and they determined , if ever they had the chance , to punish him as he deserved . they had not long to wait . after walking for some hours the old man had at last found the bamboo grove which he had made his wife carefully describe , and now he stood before it crying out : " where is the tongue - cut sparrow 's house ? where is the tongue - cut sparrow 's house ? "

question: what did the man do when he saw the house ?
answer1: hastened to the door and knocked loudly
answer4: he hastened to the door and knocked loudly
text: at last he saw the eaves of the house peeping out from amongst the bamboo foliage . he hastened to the door and knocked loudly . when the servants told the gentleman sparrow that his old master was at the door asking to see him , he was somewhat surprised at the unexpected visit , after all that had taken place , and he wondered not a little at the boldness of the old man in venturing to come to the house . the gentleman sparrow , however , was a polite bird , and so he went out to greet the old man , remembering that he had once been his master .

text: at last he saw the eaves of the house peeping out from amongst the bamboo foliage . he hastened to the door and knocked loudly . when the servants told the gentleman sparrow that his old master was at the door asking to see him , he was somewhat surprised at the unexpected visit , after all that had taken place , and he wondered not a little at the boldness of the old man in venturing to come to the house . the gentleman sparrow , however , was a polite bird , and so he went out to greet the old man , remembering that he had once been his master .

question: why did the old man not even stop to thank the gentleman sparrow ?
answer1: he was rude .
answer4: he began to hurry homewards
text: the old man intended , however , to waste no time in words , he went right to the point , without the least shame , and said : " you need not trouble to entertain me as you did my old woman . i have come myself to get the box which she so stupidly left behind . i shall soon take my leave if you will give me the big box - that is all i want ! " the gentleman sparrow at once consented , and told his servants to bring out the big box . the old man eagerly seized it and hoisted it on his back , and without even stopping to thank the gentleman sparrow began to hurry homewards .

question: what happened because the box was so heavy ?
answer1: the old man could not walk fast , much less run .
answer4: he could not walk fast
text: the box was so heavy that he could not walk fast , much less run , as he would have liked to do , so anxious was he to get home and see what was inside the box , but he had often to sit down and rest himself by the way . while he was staggering along under the heavy load , his desire to open the box became too great to be resisted . he could wait no longer , for he supposed this big box to be full of gold and silver and precious jewels like the small one his wife had received .

question: what was in the big box ?

answer4: a number of horrible and frightful looking demons
text: at last this greedy and selfish old man put down the box by the wayside and opened it carefully , expecting to gloat his eyes on a mine of wealth . what he saw , however , so terrified him that he nearly lost his senses . as soon as he lifted the lid , a number of horrible and frightful looking demons bounced out of the box and surrounded him as if they intended to kill him . not even in nightmares had he ever seen such horrible creatures as his much - coveted box contained . a demon with one huge eye right in the middle of its forehead came and glared at him , monsters with gaping mouths looked as if they would devour him , a huge snake coiled and hissed about him , and a big frog hopped and croaked towards him . the old man had never been so frightened in his life , and ran from the spot as fast as his quaking legs would carry him , glad to escape alive . when he reached home he fell to the floor and told his wife with tears all that had happened to him , and how he had been nearly killed by the demons in the box .

question: what will happen when the cat tries to get the ring back ?

text: " they must have the ring back again , " she said to the cat . the cat answered : " the ring has been carefully locked up in the chest , where no one can get at it . " " you must catch a mouse , " said the dog , " and the mouse must gnaw a hole in the chest and fetch out the ring . and if he does not want to , say that you will bite him to death , and you will see that he will do it . " this advice pleased the cat , and he caught a mouse . then he wanted to go to the house in which stood the chest , and the dog came after . they came to a broad river . and since the cat could not swim , the dog took him on her back and swam across with him . then the cat carried the mouse to the house in which the chest stood . the mouse gnawed a hole in the chest , and fetched out the ring . the cat put the ring in his mouth and went back to the river , where the dog was waiting for him , and swam across with him . then they started out together for home , in order to bring the lucky ring to their mistress and master . but the dog could only run along the ground ; when there was a house in the way she always had to go around it . the cat , however , quickly climbed over the roof , and so he reached home long before the dog , and brought the ring to his mistress . then his mistress said to her husband : " what a good creature the cat is ! we will always give him enough to eat and care for him as though he were our own child ! " but when the dog came home they beat her and scolded her , because she had not helped to bring home the ring again . and the cat sat by the fireplace , purred and said never a word . then the dog grew angry at the cat , because he had robbed her of her reward , and when she saw him she chased him and tried to seize him . and ever since that day cat and dog are enemies .
